Furious 7 is great. It has lots of action, unstop, lots of very pretty half-dressed girls, many chases, men fighting men hand to hand and with all kinds of weapons, women fighting women hand to hand, lots of impossible feats made possible somehow, some sentimentality, and much destruction - it seems that an entire city is destroyed. Viewers who like this kind of action will thrill while watching this film.
The crew had hurt the younger brother of an ex-British special ops agent who was so lethal the British retired him. This is Jason Statham. Jason decides to get revenge, to kill the entire team. They need to find him and stop him.
Meanwhile, the US government tells Vin Diesel that if he and his team will get a computer drive back to the government, the government will lend it to the team to help find Jason. The task given them seems impossible  thats why the government had to turn to the team.

My favorite out of all the Fast & Furious movies, the final film in the franchise with Paul Walker (R.I.P.) is exciting, and full of the family moments that make this franchise great. The ending, while pretending to be the crew accepting the character Brian commiting to the family life as a House-Husband, they are actually saying goodbye to Paul Walker, who tragically died before filming was complete. Still, his brother stepped in to be the body double and they CGI'd his face on, so they can film Paul's Final scenes, and honestly, that final beach scene made everyone in my theater weep, because they all knew what it really meant.

The 5th movie in the series was a sort of reboot and had a clever ending introducing a new character. In the 6th we said goodbye to another and welcomed one back. In the 7th we said another good bye and just when you thought they'd done it all it gets even more intense. I won't spoil it for others, but this was the movie in which Paul Walker had been killed in real life and it was amazing that they were able to get the movie out. There are some very memorable lines from the movie, among my favorites are:

Brian to Dom: "Cars don't fly"
Dom to Letty: Its about time
And Dominick's thoughts at the end (a tribute to Paul Walker):  No matter where you are, whether it's a quarter-mile away or halfway around the world, you'll always be with me and you'll always be my brother

I can't wait for the next installments in the long running series. I hope you enjoyed it as much as I did.

This review will focus on the Sound an Video rather than the movie itself -

This set includes a 4K UHD disc, 1080p Blu-Ray disc and an Ultraviolet copy (which I believe also redeems in UHD). The UHD disc requires an "Ultra HD Blu-Ray" player. My copy also include a coupon for a free ticket to The Fate of the Furious (Fast & The Furious 8). For the current price of 20-bucks, it's a great set.

With most recent titles being a 2k upscale to 4k, I've found there to be an upgrade.. but a small one. This set has a surprisingly noticeable upgrade in 4K. When viewed on an OLED TV, the colors and clarity really stood out over the already very-good Blu-Ray disc. Video shows a small amount of grain/noise, but it's all nicely done. The sound is a bit of a controversy as it's lossy.. but on my (non-atmos) receiver it sounded great. Lots of punch and clear surround.

Overall, highly recommended set. After recent disappointing 4K discs or minimal upgrades, this was a great treat!

I never thought I would like the F&F series, but one day I was bored and watched one of them on TV--and liked it.  I also liked Paul Walker.  I was saddened by the loss of this handsome young actor and decided to buy this, his last movie.  There is an over abundance of action, so much that you have to suspend your idea of reality and just kick back and enjoy.  Flying cars and explosions abound, as well as bullets and martial art fights--its all there.  Oh, yeah, attractive men as well.  I know they had to use stand-ins for Paul's character in some of the scenes, but it was very hard to tell.  There is some suggestive language but no sex scenes.  Dom's girlfriend is a Tough Chick who runs around with a sour expression all through the movie, like she bit into a sour grape.  Mostly this is just a roaring good romp.  I just ordered the set of F&F--I guess I am a convert!

Nope.  I've watched every entry in the series and I just can't do it anymore.  1st-genuinely good, 2nd-terrible, 3rd-probably the best, 4th through 6th-morphed into a summer popcorn flick but it worked. Which leaves us with this dud; stealth choppers in LA? Check! Dialogue that says "oh no, they have armor piercing rounds" that literally bounce off said armored vehicle? Yup! More explosions than a Michael Bay movie? Of course! Re-using scenes from prior movies? Sure! At this point it's clear that they've run out of any semblance of coherent ideas and just keep throwing stuff against the wall.  Honestly, 15 year old me would think this movie was terrible; that said the best part of the movie was the ending tribute.  At least they got that part right.

I love an entertaining movie as much as the next person... Every time I tried to enjoy it they would do something else to make me want to turn it off. Unbelievable in soo many scenes I couldn't count, cheese overload, soo many plot holes there wasn't a plot left really.

The only thing I'm left with is, I think people only like it because they feel bad Paul Walker died.

Okay, I'll be honest - if I hadn't got this movie in a box set I probably wouldn't have bothered to watch it at all. But I did so I did and here's what I think...

Firstly this is the 7th movie in the franchise of Fast and Furious. The movie itself it dedicated to Paul Walker (plays Brian) who died in a car crash during a break from the filming. At this point let me state that if I didn't know the movie wasn't finished I wouldn't have guessed - it is fairly difficult to pick out when it is Paul vs stand-in - so that was obviously done well. This movie picks up with Han dead in Tokyo and Dom bringing him home to bury - at the same time we are introduced to a new bad-guy (the brother of the one from no 6 who also isn't really dead). I can't really say much more for the plot because over the course of the almost 2 1/2 hours my attention wasn't held..oh, the Letty and Dom on-off thing was frustrating and was like watching teenagers who needed to grow up.

What's wrong with the movie? Where do I start...There are far too many characters who aren't needed. This movie could have been completed without Hobbs at all or Elena. The movie goes from one bang-crash to another with no one suffering any bad injuries...really it was like they were all super-human. It was distracting. This series was good because people liked the humaness of the characters. This movie is just a disaster from beginning to end. I won't be watching the next....3 that are supposed to be made unless they cull the characters, get a plot that makes sense, and hold back on the CGI effects.

Furious 7 rocks!

Furious 7 is the latest installment of the Fast and the Furious series and the classic go-for-broke mentality follows the films that preceded it in the series, however, it seemed this movie had much more to offer than the on screen story. Part way through the film, Paul Walker was killed in a devastating car accident which shook the movies production all together. With the help of computer graphics and Walkers younger brothers Caleb and Cody, Furious 7 was finally brought to fruition on the big screen.
Dominic Toretto (Vin Diesel) is a man who thrives off of strong faith, will, and family as he sets out to protect the ones he loves the most throughout the film as an act of revenge. The movie jumps out of the gate with the surprising death of Han (Sung Kang), one of the main characters from previous films in the series, and an explosion at the Los Angeles home of Toretto and his longtime friend Brian OConnor (Paul Walker). The acts of terror are brought to the big screen by an Englishman named Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham), whose main objective was to find Toretto and his entourage, who through brute force put DSS agent Luke Hobbs (Dwayne The Rock Johnson) in the hospital for a majority of the movie to get necessary information seeing as Hobbs and Toretto worked together closely in the last film. As a result, Toretto assembles his team of old friends and battles for his threatened manhood, and safety.
Dwayne Johnson brings to life the role of Hobbs through his built frame and serious attitude which brings a much needed presence to this opening hand to hand combat scene. This antagonist role is played by Jason Statham wonderfully with his emotionless expressions and raspy voice that gives viewers the chill down their spine that an enemy should evoke.
Like any other Fast and Furious installment, this one comes with plenty of action scenes packed with unique camera tricks that director James Wan made good use of in previous films he directed including the Insidious films, and The Conjuring. The action of this movie really gave Wan the ability to use his camera tricks to his advantage and give the movie an extra dynamic that was visually appealing to the viewer while keeping them on their toes.
The plot of this film is so vast and action packed that its difficult to fully encompass, although the plot doesnt matter much with these films. The main objective of the Fast and Furious films is to throw its audience into an action packed, memorable chapter in the lives of Dominic Toretto and his family, which is the money making line when it comes to the main group of actors whose appearances can be found throughout all seven movies. This unity of having so many memories throughout the whole series really makes the family concept believable throughout Furious 7 and the solid two hours and twenty minutes the movie decides to fill with visually appealing settings, cars, and action.
The final scene of Furious 7 is a very touching tribute to the late Paul Walker, which will bring any big fan of Paul Walker and the series to tears. The film shows flashbacks to prior films that involved Diesel and Walker and features an overhead shot of the twos cars going their separate ways on a dividing highway. With Walker appearing in 6 of the 7 films, he was the centerpiece of the series and a very emotional tribute featuring outstanding flashbacks was the best way for Furious 7 to end. Knowing that this was the last time you would see Paul hanging off of a cliff, holding onto a bus for dear life, or seeing him grip the racing wheel of a European tuner one last time as Brian really made the experience a special one for fans everywhere.

Great film, if you are a 17 year old-never-had-a-real-date-with-no-life-WWE-fanboy male who is delusional enough to believe he would ever actually stand a chance dating one of the many scantily clad women in this film, who chokes his cat while fantasizing about impossibly tricked out cars he will never drive let alone ever own, who believes The Scorpion King really was a historical figure, and who aspires to be the best Call of Duty player on the planet as his one, all time, great achievement in life, and could care less about smart writing, real storylines of any depth, or any decent acting. Otherwise, the production qualities of the film are on par with the best money can buy in Hollywood for a major studio action film, ... ample amounts of action-fight scenes, stellar -although impossibly unrealistic -stunt/action scenes, great locations, good visuals, on target, high energy modern music score, and pretty decent editing .... in short, pretty much what one who is a typical fan of such movies, in it's target demographic, might expect. In that regard, if you liked all the other films in this franchise, you are likely to enjoy this one, ... really, this should have been marketed as Science Fiction and Fantasy, though, for it's many totally impossible stunt and action sequences. For this genre of film, you get what you pay for, if it's your kind of thing, and you don't mind totally nonsensical scenarios that demand you not only suspend disbelief, but actually abandon all conscious thought, then you won't be disappointed with this film. Hey, it's Vin Diesel and The Rock, ... what do you expect?

What happened here?  I laughed out loud after Vin Diesel's first line, both the writing and his delivery were so incredibly bad.  I think the first twenty minutes are worth watching just because you will not believe what a self-parody this "action" film is.  It is strangely to films, the first half ending after a miserably filmed car sequence and moving to "the Middle East" and then ending with a shootout that was aborted at the beginning.  Actions films like these are always preposterously implausible.  That is part of the fun of watching them.  I liked the Fast and Furious 1-3 even before it became Fast and Furious (those articles in front of the adjectives just took up too much space).  But Furious7 actually takes it itself seriously, so seriously that I could not help laughing over and over again.  It does all the terrible things it does on purpose.  I figured once the car porn stuff got started about 30 minutes, all of the heavy, melodramatic bilge would just go away and we'd have car porn for the rest of the film.  But no.  All of the bogus heavy-handed romance of the first 30 minutes comes back until the car porn starts up again.  And in the second part, there are two car jumps, one right after the other, just as there are two title sequences at the beginning of the film and then two songs to transition between the two halves.  Someone really meant to design this film this exact way.  Either that or the writer and director were acting some kind of death drive, a repetition compulsion.  This film actually feels like it is itself a videogame, as if the acting and pacing were timed to make the actors look and sound like robots.  Kurt Russell does manage to shine through.

"Furious 7" is a non-stop thrill ride that delivers on every front.  Diesel and crew are back on the job in more exotic locales (this time Abu Dhabi).  I especially enjoyed the cameo by Ronda Rousey. It's great to see an action-adventure film that makes the women as badass as the men. Letty (Michelle Rodriguez) may have lost her memory but none of her hot-as-heck (and I'm a woman!) swagger and kick-butt ability, although I was somewhat disappointed in Jordana Brewster's lesser role (perhaps she was too busy with "Dallas'?) The story never bogs down and moves seamlessly, and even the most unbelievable stunts are so well done that the viewer feels the experience.

7 manages to pay tribute to its losses without becoming maudlin.  Lost characters Han and Gisele get a moving farewell, and of course the ending tribute to Paul Walker had my whole cinema in tears. This was beautifully done and fans must applaud the cast's decision not to take the easy way out and simply kill off his character. Can't wait for 8!

Furious 7 (2015). Rated PG-13. Single-Disc. Running Time: 2 hours, 17 mins.
Directed by James Wan.

Returning: Paul Walker, Vin Diesel, Michelle Rodriguez, Sung Kang, Jordana Brewster, Tyrese Gibson, Ludacris, Dwayne Johnson, Elsa Pataky, Jason Statham, Lewis Black, Luke Evans, Noel Gugliemi, Benjamin Blankenship, John Cenatiempo.

Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham) wants revenge after what Hobbs (Dwayne Johnson) and Dom (Vin Diesel) did to his brother Owen (Luke Evans).
  Dom and Letty (Michelle Rodriguez) drive to Rosamond for the Race Wars, but the crowd becomes too much for Letty to handle. She still hasn't fully covered from her past accident and years of memory loss. Later, at her mock gravestone in the cemetery, she decides to leave Dom and the relationship.
  Dom visits Brian (Paul Walker) and while taking to  Mia (Jordana Brewster), discovers she is pregnant. She wants Brian to quit these dangerous adventures. Someone left a package on Brian and Mia's doorstep. Shaw sets off the explosive. Dom, Brian, Mia and child are fine, but the house is gone.
  With all this and Han (Sung Kang) dead, it is time for Dom's racing team to get back together and go after Deckard Shaw.

Also in the cast: Kurt Russell, Natalie Emmanuel, John Brotherton, Tony Jaa, Djimon Hounsou, Romeo Santos.

Paul Walker died November 30, 2013, age 40, while taking a day off from filming and attending a charity event in Valencia, California. He decided to be a passenger in a show automobile that ended up in a car accident, crashed into a tree, exploded and burned him and the driver to death.
  This film was re-written and they used as much already-filmed footage of Paul Walker as they could. They finished scenes using CGI-effects and Paul's brothers, Caleb and Cody as stand-ins and voice-actors.

In-film advertising: 7-Up, Rockstar, Corona.

Filmed in Willow Springs Motorsports Park, Rosamond, Coachella Valley, Los Angeles, California.
 Aspen Ranch, Woodland Park, Colorado.
 Social Circle, Atlanta, Fort Gilllem, Forest Park, Norcross, Georgia.
Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.
Montecristi, Dominican Republic.

Option of Language and subtitles: English, Spanish, French, DVS Descriptive Video Service.

Bonus: Back to the Starting Line, Snatch and Grab, Race Wars, Making of Fast & Furious Supercharged Ride for Universal Studios.

I didn't expect much of this movie and it sure delivered! Vin Diesal has an ego the size of Texas. Back in Fast Five as if the idea of him beating The Rock in a fight wasn't ludicrous enough, (no pun intended) he has proven to be superhuman, driving headfirst off cliffs, playing chicken with Jason Stathom, taking multiple hits to the head with a wrench, and he just shakes it off! I love The Rock but didn't know it was possible to fall out of a building and actually survive. Besides Jason Stathom getting revenge for his brother, the plot lost me. After an hour into the movie I just stopped watching it. Lost interest. I loved the action movies of yesteryear like the Die Hards, Lethel Weapons, Rambos while far fetched contained a decent amount of realism. This movie was idiotic. But what do I know? Second highest grossing movie of the year, 3 more in the works, and Vin Diesal wants an Oscar for Best Picture! Ohh the possibilities! What is this world coming too?!!!

The most ludicrous movie I've tried to watch in some time.  My wife wanted to watch it through to the end.  But with about an hour to go, I cried "Uncle!"  So I took off to clean up the kitchen, then took the dogs out for a poop.  Any of which was far more enjoyable than this.  What's worse:  the movie was still playing when I returned.  Oh, the humanity!!

Expect plenty of pretend action and crappola CGI effects, folks.  Add the dumbest script ever and Van Diesel's signature mumbling, and it's pretty painful.

If you must insist on trying it, do yourself a favor and quit after about 30 or 40 minutes.  Every minute thereafter represents a moment in time that may be appreciated in some other way.  Life is short, folks.  Run the other way.

If you're a fan of suspension of disbelief and are also of the impression that cars are indestructable and can fly between buildings, then this is the movie for you! With a self referential nod and a wink to the absurdity that unfolds on screen, the ensemble cast zooms along and embraces the insanity of the action and dialogue. The frenetic pace of the movie doesn't allow the viewer to digest how improbable the previous scene was, because we're already onto the next scene of preposterous action fueled high-jinks. The caliber of action stars in this movie is off the charts and I look forward to future installments when Dwayne Johnson has to carry a physical rock the size of his cars and smash it furiously into the audience's sense of wonderment.

Unfortunately, I have to admit that this is the first film I've seen in the "Furious" franchise.  I purchased the DVD for only three reasons.  I wanted to see the fight sequence between Michelle Rodriguez and Rhonda Rousey  I'm certainly a big fan of Rhonda's and wanted to see how Michelle did against her.  I also wanted to see the legendary actor, Kurt Russell, in action.  I've been an avid fan of Kurt's for over three decades, and I was hoping to see him do his thing, which he did in spades.  He may be back for Furious 8.  Last, I wanted to see the fantastic car-jump scene between three buildings in Abu Dhabi.  These three scenes were all I hoped they would be, and certainly much more.

What surprised me, however, is just how much I found myself enjoying the entire movie.  This isn't Lawrence of Arabia or The Bridge Over the River Kwai, but I rated it 5-stars because for its genre, the film delivers on what it promises and clearly holds your interest to the last minute.  I especially loved the hand-to-hand combat sequences between Jason Statham and Dwayne Johnson and Vin Diesel.

One last thing, even though Paul Walker passed away when the film was only halfway through completion, the production company still managed to finish the movie with the help of Paul's two brothers and CSI efftects.  For me, it was like Paul Walker was in the entire film.

I am not the target audience for this franchise but I enjoyed previous installments, specifically 5, and I like the actors. This one however I disliked from the beginning when the secondary villain caused significant damage to a hospital caring for his brother and then instructed the staff in the room to provide the best care for his brother, never mind that he'd just significantly negatively effected their ability to do so. Instead of impressing me I thought the villain stupid. But a worse sequence in my opinion is when Hobbs found same villain hacking the agency's files where Hobbs works and basically began a conversation with him instead of immediately halting the hack. Just found it totally unbelievable that a top security agent would stand chatting while a criminal hacked his files. It was the villain's audacity, I get it, that the writer was trying to show but what stood out for me was Hobbs' non-response. It's believable that a top security agent wouldn't expect to find a criminal stealing from him and in his face about it, but the writer had Hobbs respond in a way totally unbelievable. I'd much rather have had Hobbs immediately launch himself at the villain and been defeated in that fight, rather than initiate a conversation. For me, a conversation was the exact wrong thing a proactive security agent would do if he encountered such an in your face criminal. I admit I've never, to my knowledge, met a top security agent, but my opinion of U.S. government anti-terrorist agencies is that they're very, I'd argue extremely, proactive. An agent, in my opinion, would've immediately attempted to halt the theft, never mind conversing with the criminal. So the film lost me there. Everything following that was noise and property damage. I gave it 2 stars, one for crazy stunts and one because it was in focus. Disliked the music. Totally disbelieved that a bunch of scantily clad young women would be in the middle of the desert to observe race wars. I was thinking heat exhaustion, sun stroke, where's the water. And the guy took a punch from Letty with no problem, without even an insult muttered under his breath. Yeah, right. It would've been more believable if he'd reacted honestly to being punched in the mouth, and then caught Dom eyeballing him and decided to amend his first response. That at least would've helped the story seem somewhat grounded in reality. They need another writer cause whoever's writing their scripts, if they keep going like this, is going to trash the franchise.

Reminds me a lot of the Suicide Squad, actually, and I hadn't thought of that angle before now... hmm...

So I have no idea why people are gushing about the ending, but that is apparently why they're giving it 5 stars. Ignore the entire movie, and if the ending has some sappy farewell to the actor who passed away, all is forgiven. Can someone please tell me why people are so idiotic? I'm glad Chris Nolan didn't follow this recipe for The Dark Knight, otherwise Batman would have held a big beautiful ceremony for the Joker at the end.

It goes without saying that this was the worst of the series. But if you want to throw you money at a nonsensical story, more power to you. Who am I to try and convince anyone that this movie made no sense? That it was written for 12-year old boys? That might explain the reviews...

Overall it was an okay movie. Certain scenes were a hokey, and the humor in some parts felt forced as opposed to previous versions where it came off more natural. Ronda Rousey had a small roll in the movie, and although the girl can break you in half in the octagon, she simply cannot act (truth be told, her lines sucked too). If I was disappointed by anything it was that the villain (Deckard Shaw played by Jason Statham) was simply not believable. From the very beginning he came across as a bad guy from a comic book rather than an action film. Like Rousey's lines, and the rest of the general humor, his presence was also forced.

7 movies in, I can see how it's getting harder to sustain that same adrenaline rush we got from F&F1 & 2F,2F. But this one went way off the rails and by itself is entertaining, but not a good follow-up to such a entertaining series. If anything needed to change, they should have removed half the humor, given Rousey better lines (or no lines at all; just let her scowl at you and let the punches fly), and focused more on the car chasing in either direction.

In spite of all that, the ending was very nicely done. It was subtle, but direct and was a nice tribute.

This movie blew me away in theaters, but there's so much going on, you don't realize what an incredible motion picture it is until the second viewing. The cinematography, the filming (notably of a particular fight scene between Statham and the Rock), the story, just outstanding. And moments that genuinely make you laugh. And of course the final scene, which in theaters had three grown men on the verge of tears. But some of us really feel like we grew up with Paul Walker. If a film can take you through a range of emotions and manage to resolve at the end, it is truly a great film in my humble opinion. Amazing. I'm going to watch it a third time very soon.

Not quite sure what to make of this release. Paul Walkers passing really effects the flow of this film. It feels rushed in some scenes and suddenly cut in others, giving a very convoluted vibe. Obviously this can't be held against James Wan as I'm sure he did the best with the time he had. The CGI and ending was very tastefully and respectfully done - It really shines through in these films that these people really care about each other.

The scenes involving bimbos and up-skirts came across as tacky and out of place. I like looking at ladies as much as the next straight guy, but considering how much these films have changed - it just felt stuck on for no added benefit.

In terms of the product, I'm a bit disappointed that they didn't do a deeper segment into Paul Walker in the special features. Considering this was his last film, it would of been nice to see some never before seen footage and possibly an interview with the cast reflecting on their friendship with Paul or how it was working with him through the franchise.

Overall, while this film may not hold a candle to Fast 5 and 6 - it still comes recommended to any F&F fan.

This movie only goes so high on my rating scale because I think Paul Walker did his part in this movie, and because he is the entire heart of the Fast & Furious franchise.  His charm and energy radiate in this last installment of his, and I nearly teared up from his exit from the screen.  Pual, RIP and know that you were one of the greats in my book!

But let's analyze the rest of the film.. I feel like the action was over-the-top, which i admit I do like in certain instances.  However, I feel like the acting was riddled with flawed one-liners, attempting to make the characters (especially Diesel's) stand out as bad-asses.  I hated every time they spouted this nonesense.  I also felt like this last action sequences were stroking Diesel's ego, if you're gonna play dead just to torment your on-screen-wife, you're a jerk.

I can understand that a lot of mixed reviews about this movie are justified, because i'm certainly divided.  But I think this was a fairly good film if you can cover your ears during the at times horrid line deliveries.  In my final opinion,  the franchise should end here, because Paul's exit will certainly be imprinted in everyone's minds, and it was a fantastic way to end.

I will admit that I have never been a huge F&F fan but I have enjoyed the action sequences and cool looking cars.  With this movie series, you know exactly what you are going to get with no surprises.  As it is with sequels, some movies in the series have been better than others and at times the sequels had more flash than story.  So I expected a bit more of the same with Furious 7 and in some ways they don't change what the series is noted for with its fast cars, wild stunts and action packed sequences.  To my surprise, this has a better story this time around and a good villain with the addition of Jason Statham who is always comfortable in this type of role, good guy or bad.  I also like the addition of Kurt Russell as well.  Granted the stunts are a bit over the top but this movie brings the fun back to the F&F series.  I do feel the movie is a bit too long though at over 2 hours and 20 minutes.  I do say that the tribute to Paul Walker is a nice touch and to me (even though I know the F&F don't want to hear it) this is a great way to send off the series.  I personally don't think it would be the same series without Walker.

I call it profit pandering when all that the producers ask of the writer and director is to make sure there are as many formula scenes (movie history has proven these to be money makers) as possible to attract the widest audience.
Check out the proof:
1. Prolonged close up shots of the rear ends (said this way to bypass Amazon censors) of bikini, barely clad, humans. Check!
2. Prolonged close up shots of the males who compensate for their small appendage (said this way to bypass Amazon censors) by over pumping (exaggerating) the male antlers (i.e. muscle). A skill acquired first by practice posturing in front of their full length mirrors. Males further enhance their displays by seeming to always be wearing tight tees (if at all) with small sleeves to promote those antlers. So much non-functional muscle that if they tried running they might outrun a sloth. Check!
3. Furthering this theme is the storyline of "muscle" cars accompanied by prolonged close ups of "pushing the pedal to the metal" and massaging the manual shift with the that standard coup de grce - squealing tires. Oh, and the car drop from airplane - done before. Check!
4. Assault on bad guy fortress - done so many times in film it has actually become boring. Fight scenes - an Oscar for camera angles. Bruce Lee, if he could see this, would be laughing in his Lake View home. Check!
5. Dialogue? Written for that part of the audience that struggled to pass sophomore English in high school. Check!
6. Inject into the storyline the latest pop news headlines caption grabber - terrorists and hackers. Check!

With 230 cars in the film, car buffs will love it...if you can stand seeing them get crushed.  Like the villain's Aston Martin DB9 that is involved in a head-on collision.  This is a good vs. bad, fast vs. slower adventure featuring more than car chases and stunts.  Vin Diesel is his usual macho but winsome self wooing his lady.  Picture a Dodge Challenger, Plymouth 'Cuda, Bugatti Veyron, Jeep Wrangler, Subaru Impreza and a Nissan GTR with 700 horses.  The Supercar, though, deserves its own statement:  The Lykan HyperSport made in the Middle East, has a max speed of 240 mph and goes from zero to 60mph in less than 3 seconds and costs over $3.5 million.  And wait until you see WHERE it goes.  Think of Mission Impossible in world-renown cities building to more than a smashing conclusion.  As a final note:  While this film was being produced, actor Paul Walker died in his car so his brothers stepped in to take his place in the film.

Absolute trash.

This movie is so bad, but it's not even funny bad.  I don't care about Paul Walker....I was just after a halfway decent movie for Friday night.  Combination of stilted, foot-in-mouth, twee dialogue delivered by actors who could barely pass an infomercial audition, completely off-the-wall stunts that leave physics in their rear-view mirror, INCREDIBLY boring car chases, and the sort of puerile, high-schooler attitude towards life and "romance" (sexiness) that is just nauseating to anyone who's ever actually matured past puberty.....leaves you reeling with amazement at its inadequacies, of which there are many.

This movie was literally written and made for the packs of teenaged zombies that we call younger people nowadays.  Thumping hip-hop, nary a good actor anywhere to be seen, and the most lame excuse for a plot that exists only to throw in a peppering of opportunities for the men to look even more po-faced and the women to lose even more garments amidst the supposed-to-be-crises that they are supposed-to-be-dealing with.

Aside:  They should have hired Top Gear's Clarkson/Hammond/May to make and film the car chases, a-la their one episode with The Sweeney.  They made a car chase with a Ford Focus and an under-powered Jaguar driven by an overweight car show host and a confused Armenian look (and feel) more exciting than ANY of the absolute trash contained in Furious 7.

Just yesterday evening, I was at the grocery store and there's a movie rental place there. I originally was asking him if they had "San Andreas," but he said not for another day.

We started talking about "Furious 7" and that I was just about to go see it on April 3rd when I got sick, and stayed sick, including having a stroke, the whole time it was in theaters.

So I finally just bought it last week, and it was about time I saw it! Totally worth the wait, and I told him that the only time I noticed that Brian was not Paul was when he had a close up, talking with 'Hello Kitty,' (cause I couldn't and can't remember her name [memory still lagging from the stroke], and it was the scene right after Letty says, "Hello Kitty's awake." LOL!) All I said at that moment was, "That is not Paul."

But the rest of it was spot on! Especially the very end when they show him twice in the car.
The guy at the video store told me that was actually done using CGI with one of his brothers, and I couldn't believe it.

I had to assume that they took video from one of the previous movies in order to get those shots, but I am just stunned at how well that came out by using his brother! Simply unreal!

I keep watching that end scene over and over with tears in my eyes! Just can't help myself!

But I asked him if he knew about the order that the movies are meant to be watched now. He said no, he had never heard of any certain order. So I told him that since "Tokyo Drift" was so out of place, especially with Han, the series should be watched as, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 3, 7.

I told him, that first of all, Han's story in #3, brings about so much confusion and makes no sense as to why he's in #4, 5 & 6. But then during the credits of #6, it shows that exact scene of Han from #3, from a different standpoint. But it's still the same scene. But it sets everything up for #7.

Then in #7, we see it happen again near the start of the movie, putting things together. In #3, we also saw a cameo of Dom at the very end, about to race the main character. In #7, we see Dom talking to him more in depth, along with some of the other characters from #3, who are still teenagers, as they were at the time that movie was made in... 2006 I believe???

So that places the events of #3 nine years ahead of the time it was released, to the same time as #7 was released. Therefore the reason the movies should be watched in this order... 1, 2, (4, 5, 6), 3, (7... [8, 9] )...?
(Movies in parentheses are trilogies, and trilogies that have not yet been released (in brackets within parentheses.

I have seen people say "this is the best Fast and the Furious movie to date", and if you're going on the criteria of "cohesive storyline and action sequences", that's probably true. However, if you're watching for cool cars, races, and shenanigans, you will find yourself more disappointed than I was with any other movie that's come out in the last year (which I had high hopes for). The whole film is more like Die Hard meets the Three (6?) stooges, but in any good way. Statham's character was far less interesting than I'd hoped for, and the ludicrous scene where both he and Diesel walk away from a high speed front end collisions with nothing more than wobbly gaits and tricklingly bloodied noses made me scoff out loud, "suspend belief"? Sure, but there are some things that just make me irritated with Hollywood's brashness in the face of grounded story telling.

By the end of it, where everyone was probably crying, I was bored. I didn't know Paul Walker, he was a boring actor that always came off stiff to me and while I didn't wish him ill, much less death, I don't care enough I needed a 20 minute long goodbye scene so I could pine on with sobs like he was my best friend.

The movie gets a solid B- for being pretentious and irritatingly over the top.

Bias Alert: I am a huge fan of action movies an the Furious collection is one of the better series. I cannot really think of a negative here, I saw it in the theatre and I just watched the dvd. If you are a fan of the Furious films then you will not be disappointed. They also provided a wonderful tribute to the memory of Paul Walker. I truly enjoy fight scenes done by Vin Disel and/or Jason Statham in all there movies. But the best fight scene involves two other characters in this film and that was truly an unexpected bonus. What makes this such a great film is its appeal to everybody; there is comedy, there is romance, there is drama and of course there is action. Did I mention action, hand to hand action, car action, chopper action and plane action, hand gun and street fight action.

THIS MOVIE IS AWESOME!!!! I am NOT going into the plot/story of this movie. If you have seen the previous six movies in the series, you will NOT be disappointed. The action is awesome!! The continuity of the storyline is very well presented and the "family" concept is also very well presented. The loss of Paul Walker is given a wonderful and heartfelt farewell, in a way that only the original cast members can show. His brothers represented his loss in the latter parts of the movie so very well. You actually don't feel like Paul is missing at all. I don't know how well they can continue the movie franchise, but Fast and Furious so far has been a grand ride on the big screen!!!! YOU HAVE GOT TO SEE THIS MOVIE!!! And...those of you who just have to be critical of a movie of this high caliber....have just got to be brain dead!!! lolol........

I really really wanted to LOVE this movie. But in my opinion (YES MY OPINION, so hate me quietly), I think they did an injustice to Paul's memory by subbing his brother's bodies and his face through out. When I saw it in theaters I thought it was weird, and everyone (mostly men) seemed very emotionally attached to this idea. They used clipped scenes with solo Paul, the group talking and the him alone. They did a poor job of dubbing his face/voice over his brothers. And the story line seemed very weak. I did like the final drive at the end. It would have been nice to have a beautiful story saved for the credits/bonus features, and a truly good complete story line with wonderful graphics and scenes than a mosh up memorial movie they did. I think it would have been much better to write him out of the major story line (maybe held captive) and killed or an "I'm done I have a family to think about" scene. Also his wife was rarely in it too.

I'm quite a latecomer to the FAST & FURIOUS franchise, having gotten on with the fourth entry, but not really liking it until FAST FIVE. Here we are, seven films in, the series has morphed into something else entirely different from the street racing formula it started as. While the previous two were heist films, FURIOUS 7 goes into full superhero mode. I mean, can nothing kill these people? Still, once you embrace the absurdity there's a lot of fun to be had with the over-the-top action and quip-making. The plot, as if it really matters, involves Dom and his team going after Deckard Shaw, who is hunting them down because of what they did to his brother in the previous movie. It's actually an interesting dual family dynamic that, sadly, isn't really played up save for one scene at the beginning. That's also the scene where we're introduced to just how bada** that Shaw is by seeing the aftermath of what he did to the hospital where his brother is staying. Sadly, nothing in the rest of the film lives up to that level of awesome. Along the way, the team has to extract a hacker so that they can get some incredible piece of technology that will help them find Shaw. However, the "God's Eye" is merely a plot-driving MacGuffin that extends the running time, and kind of useless because Shaw just keeps showing up where Dom and company are anyway as the plot requires. And that's generally the biggest problem with FURIOUS 7: it relies too heavily and coincidence and convenience to drive the story. Still, the film delivers on the action it promises. Big time. The coolest stunt in the whole film is probably where they parachute cars down onto a mountain, which looked to be achieved practically (at least part of it). I can only imagine what an adrenaline rush it would have been to see it on a premium format screen (like IMAX), but it was still effective on my laptop. But, for my money, the film's best action sequence takes place in Abu Dhabi. James Wan, best known until now for directing low-budget horror films, was at his directorial best here deftly cutting between concurrent action sequences and witty banter courtesy of Roman (Tyrese). After this show-stopping segment, the final "street fight" was almost anti-climactic by comparison. As for the lulls between the action, there was plenty of talk about family as is typical for the series. Yet, none of it really felt genuine until the emotional final scene which pays tribute, and says farewell, to Paul Walker. That moment alone, out of all the other similar ones throughout the series, was heartfelt and touching without being clichd. So, is this highbrow entertainment? Heck no! But, it knows what it is and delivers what the target audience wants.

With each subsequent installment in the F&F franchise, the required level of suspension of disbelief on the part of the audience becomes that much greater.  Yes, in this latest addition there are all the requisites for a testosterone-fueled blockbuster action movie - car chases, explosions, death-defying stunts, girls in skimpy bikinis.  All that's really missing is a plausible and realistic plot, but I guess that's optional these days.  Also, can't Dwayne Johnson weary anything else but skin-tight Under Armour shirts and combat boots?  Must be what he sleeps in too.  All law enforcement offers, no matter the agency, have to wear business attire (i.e. a suit) once in a while.

**Spoiler Alert**
Something is lost on this film. Maybe it has to do with the fact that the acting is terrible or the stunts are so far over the top that even suspending reality can't pull this out of a nose dive. This movie lacks the one thing the original film had - soul. While not the greatest movie, the original had a certain charm to it. There is absolutely nothing like that in this film. You can hear that plainly in the dialog.

The best part of this film was Ronda Rousey. I really like the chick-fight scene between her and Letty. I had to laugh though because in IRL, Ronda would have obliterated her in 27 seconds.

It was like watching an amped up version of "Triple XXX". Only in this one Vin Diesel saves the world. I mean really, a terrorist flying a helicopter and a remote control drone that fires missiles on the streets of El-Ay? All the damage inflicted to the city and not one mention of who is going to clean that mess up. The movie started off great and they had me up to the point where they blew up Dominic's house. After that, the whole thing just unravels for me. The whole, car rolling down a cliff? Sh1t, that would kill anyone at the perceived speed they are rolling at. Brian hanging on to the end of a bus that is teetering on the edge of cliff and is only saved by making a well timed jump to Letty's car who, coincidentally was at the right place at the right time and was able to precisely put the rear bumper where Brian needed it to be. This is easily one of the weaker entries in the franchise.  The storyline was weak, and almost nonsensical.  There was very little fluidity in the story.  The film was edited together as though they were presenting a series of small vignettes or episodes, not one fluid movie.  The dialog was straight out of the Hollywood action movie dictionary, nothing original.  It was painfully obvious during the movie that Paul Walker had much more work to do on the film prior to his unfortunate passing.  He had very little dialog, and seemed to be along for the ride as opposed to having a more prominent role.  Jason Statham's character was ridiculous.  He must have had some sort of magical transport machine, as he managed to appear everywhere that Dom and his team traveled to.  Not only was Jason Statham there, he had an endless supply of vehicles and weaponry with him.  It was akin to a Friday the 13th film when Jason Vorhees shows up everywhere, despite the victims running away from him.  Dwayne Johnson was simply channeling the same character he played in the G.I. Joe sequel.  It was almost laughable.  This is the painful, honest question everyone needs to ask themselves:  Had Paul Walker not passed away, would this movie have been as successful as it was?  Would the ending that Furious 7 was given have made sense in a world where Paul Walker was still with us?  While the character of Brian O'Conner had an epiphany of sorts during the movie, it felt forced and decidedly out of character overall.  It is OK to have a "mindless" action film, but it needs to be cohesive and innovative.  Furious 7 is none of those things.

I'm all for action, but this is so over the top! I can only suspend disbelief so far, this movie asks too much of the viewer. The acting and dialogue is laughable. I really tried to like it. I was also disappointed in the HD sound. The midrange and mix in general was strange on both my high end systems. RIP Paul.

Not since Gilliam's "Brazil" or perhaps Orson Welles's "Magnificent Ambersons" has a film been so transformed by the inclusion of additional material and shown us a director's complete vision. Now the gratuitous butt shots, bulging biceps, close-ups of feet stomping on pedals and hands slamming sticks into gears are given more weight and context, exposing modern man's existential ennui as he attempts to come to terms with the cognitive dissonance of simultaneously harnessing the powers of nature in the creation and of complex machinery bound by the laws of physics while still holding onto the complex spiritual truths of "family"

There are many things in this series that I haven't appreciated, but overall, it's great entertainment, and this installment is far and away the best. While the series has always been about family, the tribute and the way they ended it was absolutely perfect. The acting was par for the course of this series, but when one combines all of the series' history, then adds the dimension of Paul Walker's death, IRL, this release IS the Fast & Furious series. It's just epic, on multiple levels.

If you have hated this series from day one, you'll hate this one too, and probably won't get to the best part(s) without turning it off. But if you liked, or even tolerated any of the previous installments, you do NOT want to miss this one, if you're a movie buff. This has less of the undesirable garbage, and such a great ending, unless you hate this series, you really need to see this. It's far and away my favorite of the series. Most importantly, because it was definitely more about family this time than any of the previous films, but with an incredible amount of action and thrills.

Just don't share it with anybody under age 13; especially if you haven't accustomed them to looking away or fast-forwarding/skipping the most violent stuff; this is a very adult movie when it comes to violence, although the language and sexuality isn't as quite as adult as some other series installments (but it IS there, for those of you with young children, two scenes in particular warrant your attention/censorship). The action is interspersed throughout the movie, and quite intense, and very well done. And the graphics are great; only in two scenes can you even tell what is rendered and what was captured from real life. The special effects team did a great job.

The soundtrack was what you would expect from F&F flick, EXCEPT for the tribute song, See You Again by Wiz Khalifa (Feat. Charlie Puth). That is an epic ending to Paul Walker's role in this series, and easily the best song of the entire series.

To be honest, if they make another Fast & Furious movie, it just might ruin it. I hope they leave this alone and move on to other projects. This is a perfect ending to the series. Hopefully they'll leave it alone; if they keep going, they'll have to be EXTREMELY sensitive to fans' expectations and preferences if they don't want to ruin it with a bomb that burns off untold $millions of investor cash. If they mess with Paul Walker's legacy, or ruin it with a half-assed encore, it will really ruin the brand and everything connected with it.

Honestly, it might be best to wait for a generation then do a reboot, IF and ONLY IF they can cast the perfect cast and do it justice. But there was only one Paul Walker, and there is only one Vin Diesel, so I don't see it happening. That combo was great for many reasons, and it can't ever happen again in this life, for obvious reasons.

So in closing, if you like Fast & Furious movies, or have liked ANY of the previous installments, DO NOT MISS THIS ONE. You'll be glad you saw this. It's very entertaining, and the tribute is just perfect. Seriously. Kudos to everyone involved in its production!

I have nothing bad to say about this movie. If you have watched all of the Fast and Furious movies then you will love this one just as much of the next. Even if you have not seen the first six movies you will enjoy this movie. If you are a car lover you will fully enjoy all of these movies and especially this one. Even a non-car lover would love this movie and would watch them over and over. Also if you are more a family type of person then this movie is for you, one of the characters says I don't have friends, I have family this movie is a great way to show that family is important and it is what it is all about. There is not a specific user for this product it is simply for everyone that enjoys a good movie.
 As we all know Paul Walker passed away during the filming of this movie, but you would never know, his character didn't have any less screen time. The writers handled the situation very well and had a great tribute to Paul. It was a respectful send-off and amazing way to show that they cared a lot about him. All of the characters were well played throughout the entire movie and you would have never known that anything bad had happened.
 There might be some areas of the movie that you might be lost if you have not seen any of the other movies, but other than that there wasn't anything I could point out wrong with this movie. I would not be able to talk bad about this movie even if it were to save my life, and neither will you if you watch it.
 This movie will be one of your favorites in the series, and if you have not seen any of the other movies it will make you want to watch of the others. You will soon become a huge fan of these movies and watch them over and over. Everyone will love the Fast and Furious movies.

Dominic and his crew thought they'd left the bad cinema behind. They had defeated stereotypical terrorist Owen Shaw and split up. But now, despite an enormous film budget, Shaw's brother, Deckard Shaw, played by a grunting and grimacing cardboard cutout wielding bagfulls of what look like practice grenades, is out making the crew feel bad by hurling both insults and the grenades, unceremoniously blowing up nearby furniture and other inanimate objects for revenge.

Worse yet, a former blood-diamond miner named Jakarde who struck it rich and purchased a military helicopter and a free license to use it within US airspace to blow up Los Angeles without any flak from the U.S. military, and another cardboard cutout character aptly named "Mr. Nobody" but actually Snake Plissken in an undercover cameo role, are both competing to steal a computer spyware program borrowed from Microsoft's Windows X that can turn any technological device into cold hard cash.

Torretto must reconvene with his team to wrench fight Shaw and retrieve the spyware program while caught in a power struggle between the former blood-diamond miner and the United States government's agent, Snake Plissken.  But luckily, like an episode of the A-Team, no one really gets hurt in this movie and there are many shiny objects and explosions to keep the viewer from noting a complete lack of realism, directorial discretion, or plot.

- IBMDB (Internet Bad Movie Database), 2/5 Stars

PS> This movie was so silly, and by that I do not mean humorous, but laugh-out-loud dumb.  It was as unrealistic as a childish superhero cartoon, which I thought was an unfitting "vehicle" for Paul Walker's well-deserved tribute and farewell.  This is no Furious 5, the last good movie in the series and the last I will watch.  This immature, half-baked movie makes Transformers look good. So we speed up to #7 in this gigantically popular action series. Dont expect much meaningful storyline, but do expect a lot of action form a crew that seems to love blowing up cars and driving them through the air and through the tall buildings of Abu Dabai and other fascinating locales. The film is overly long for the paucity of content, but for F & F fans it will satisfy.

Dominic Toretto (Vin Diesel) and his crew thought they'd left the criminal mercenary life behind. They'd defeated international terrorist Owen Shaw (Luke Evans) and went their separate ways. But now, Shaw's brother, Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham), is out killing the crew one by one for revenge. Worse, a Somalian terrorist called Jakarde (Djimon Hounsou) and a shady government official called "Mr. Nobody" (Kurt Russell) are both competing to steal a computer terrorism program called "God's Eye," that can turn any technological device into a weapon. Torretto must reconvene with his team to stop Shaw and retrieve the God's Eye program while caught in a power struggle between the terrorist and the United States government. The 7 of course are Diesel, Paul Walker, Dwayne Johnson, Tyrese Gibson, Ludacris, Michelle Rodriguez, and Lucas Black and the cast is rounded out with some other strong actors.

It is a speed action genre film and if that is your bag youll love it and likely forgive the shallow content. Grady Harp, September 15

I was kid in the local street racing scene here in New Orleans back when the first movie came out. We were quarter mile guys with semi fast cars, no drifting or anything like that. I still remember the fun we had in that theater for the first movie. Domestic vs Import guys.. Ragging each other.. after the movie we all rode out together and went to the lakefront. It was one of the best weekends I can remember. I followed the career and life of Paul Walker after that movie. He was a huge Mustang fan like myself, and had several fox body cars like mine. He was a family man and ran a charity that did so much good. He was a great person.. never in the news for drugs or DUI or any shady anything. I was saddened by his loss and the end of this movie was a touching way to send him off. The movie itself was very good! RIP Paul I hope they have some fast cars in heaven!

++Warning++ This will contain spoilers from the prior films, and hints, but no major giveaways from this movie.  If you have not seen the prior films, proceed with caution.

The film continues the tradition of the franchise by ratcheting up the action, stunts and fight sequences from the last one.  It is also very bittersweet in that it will be the last movie in which we see Paul Walker or his character Brian any longer.  Most likely anyone reading this by now knows how the film handled his character after Paul Walker died about halfway through the filming of the movie, but for those who have not I will not spoil it.  The last 5-10 minutes of the film is essentially a tribute to him, leading the the black letters For Paul, just before the credits roll.

As far as the story goes, the crux of it is that Jason Statham's character plays the brother of Shaw, the bad guy from Part 6.  He is out for revenge against everyone who took his brother down, including Hobbs, and all of Toretto's crew.  This results in a great fight sequence between The Rock and Statham early on in the movie (which takes The Rock out until the end of the film), and then a cat and mouse game between Shaw and the rest of the crew throughout the rest of the movie.  The beginning of the movie actually starts after the events of the end of Part 6, then shows what we saw at the end of the credits in Part 6, showing where Tokyo Drift fit into the sequence of films,. then picked up in the "present day."  The movie also introduces a couple new characters that may or may not be involved in the upcoming sequels including Kurt Russell as a covert military leader type helping Dom and the Crew take down Shaw, and a hacker named Ramsey.

The movie does not try to take itself too seriously.  The action sequences are very over the top, and some of the things (like The Rock flexing a cast off his arm) are just put in to be silly and almost lampoon some of the old school action movies.  There is also the family theme that has underscored the relationships of all the characters (especially at the end of the movie) which is really the only part where it does take itself seriously.  There is a great mountainside chase, that rivals any car chase sequence done in any movie, some very good fight sequences, including one between Ronda Rousey and Michelle Rodriguez, and a couple between Paul Walker and Tony Jaa.

For those who get the disc, the movie looks and sounds great on blu ray.  There are two versions of the movie included, the Theatrical and Extended version.  There is a commentary track on the movie, then a couple hours worth of making of and behind the scenes features, including showing how they pulled off many of the action sequences with as many practical effects as they could.  There is also the "See You Again" music video, and a making of the Universal Theme Park Ride.  The only thing they did not have which would have been nice to see is something about how Paul Walker's brothers were used as stand ins for him to finish his parts of the film, much in the way Brandon Lee's part in The Crow was finished after his death.

Ultimately everyone knows what the movies are and are not.  If you are looking for award winning acting and writing, this is not it.  Although I would argue that many of the actors have grown into their characters very well, and the acting and writing has become better over the span of films, it is what it is.  That said, the cinematography  and action sequences rival that seen in any movie.  The movies definitely have a blockbuster feel to them now, and it is clear the set up is for the franchise to go on.  How that will work with one of the two leads gone will remain to be seen, but this is definitely worth adding to your collection if you are a fan of the series.

Furious 7 continues the successful franchise formula with over-the-top car stunts  the films raison dtre. The plot involves villain Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham) determined to destroy the gang of car thieves led by Domin Toretto (Vin Diesel). Shaw is the older brother of Owen, who was defeated and disfigured by Dom and crew in Fast & Furious 6, and is now out for revenge. A highly trained assassin, Deckard Shaw is a seemingly unstoppable force intent on one thing only: the annihilation of Dom and his men.  A mysterious government agent known as Mr. Nobody (Kurt Russell) approaches Dom offering him a chance to get to Shaw in exchange for the retrieval of an advanced piece of espionage technology and the rescue of its creator.

This mission sets the stage for a global manhunt with cars doing things Detroit never intended, all for bigger and better thrills. Most of what occurs is pure action, with little attention to science or probability. This is the kind of movie you cant analyze too seriously; its meant to be enjoyed purely on a visceral level. In that department, Furious 7 delivers. This is the movie Paul Walker was filming when he died in an off-the-set car accident. The production shut down for several months while the writers and director James Wan tried to figure out how to complete the film without its star. Walkers brothers were hired as acting doubles and CGI images of Walker were superimposed. Because of Walkers untimely death, the film has a certain sadness underlying the vehicular mayhem.

Bonus features on the 2-disc Blu-ray/DVD Extended Edition Combo Pack include deleted scenes, music video, and several making-of featurettes.

"Furious 7" is great! This is how the story goes: Dominic and his crew thought they'd left the criminal mercenary life behind. They'd defeated international terrorist Owen Shaw and went their separate ways. But now, Shaw's brother, Deckard Shaw, is out killing the crew one by one for revenge. Worse, a Somalian terrorist called Jakarde and a shady government official called "Mr. Nobody" are both competing to steal a computer terrorism program called "God's Eye," that can turn any technological device into a weapon. Torretto must reconvene with his team to stop Shaw and retrieve the God's Eye program while caught in a power struggle between the terrorist and the United States government.

The cast led by Vin Diesel (also produced) (as Dominic Torretto), Paul Walker (as Brian O'Conner) & Dwayne Johnson (as Hobbs) is great. The directing by James Wan is great. The story & screenplay by Chris Morgan (also executive produced) is great.

The music by Brian Tyler is great. The cinematography by Stephen F. Windon & Marc Spicer is great. The film editing by Kirk Morri, Christian Wagner, Dylan Highsmith & Leigh Folsom Boyd is great. The casting by Kelly Roy & Anne McCarthy is great. The production design by Bill Brzeski is great. The art direction by Jonathan Carlos, Alan Hook, Desma Murphy & Jay Pelissier is great. And one last ride it is!!! I have to say that "Furious 7" is, in a word, fantastic. When you add a British Special Forces assassin, Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham), to the already great mix of characters, and he is the bad guy coming after Dom (Vin Diesel) and the fast crew for revenge you just know that there is going to be more action and more excitement than in any of the previous installments. Especially when Shaw gets the better of DSS agents Luke Hobbs (Dwayne Johnson) and Elena Neves (Elsa Pataky) in their first confrontation.

If that is not enough, a black operative known as, at least to himself, "Mr Nobody" (Kurt Russell) makes quite an entrance to offer assistance in exchange for a favor that Nobody needs from Dom. And, just for good measure to ensure a good time, add in some high tech (the "God's eye"), the billionaire Mose Jakande (Djimon Hounsou) from Abu Dhabi and his rockin' head of security (Ronda Rousey). They certainly do take some pristine rides to the desert.

The overall plot and sub-plots weave their way through the story and the ride is as fast and as furious as one can take. Car chases, knockdown drag-out fights, gunfire, heavy artillery, eye candy, and even flying cars...what more could one want? As with all other films in this highly entertaining franchise the comedy relief is always welcome and helps make these movies what they are. Some of the stunts and visuals are simply amazing. Unreal, yes, but loads of fun. Definitely a high octane ride! As a final note, I have to say that how the studio and fellow actors paid tribute to Brian O'Conner (Paul Walker - R.I.P.) was great, a real class act.

In terms of a product, you really get your money's-worth ... Blu-Ray, DVD, Ultraviolet and iTunes Digital Copy. And be sure to read all the code sheet as Universal also offers you the choice of a free additional UV movie.

A proper send-off to Paul Walker and his legacy. This movie had all the action you could ask for, but definitely had the 'family is all that matters' theme running through it. You could tell they really made this as a thank-you, we miss you, we are thinking of you, tribute to Walker. Even though its nearly 2 1/2 hours, you are kept engaged and interested throughout the film. Yes, some of the dialogue leaves something to be desired. If you can look past some of those 'hollywood' moments, you will be warmly rewarded with a sense that you are being included in their family, and their desire to truly thank their audience for over a decade of loyalty, and to say good-bye to someone they truly felt was family.

Do not watch this, save yourself the hours of your life this takes away. Watch Sex and the City instead.....really.

Talk about over the top! This was certainly an ambitious movie, what many Bond movies should have been. Their tuxedo moments in this movie pay homage to that, I suppose, but it is one heck of a thrill ride. It's like Bond, Mission Impossible, and Terminator rolled into one. Of course, there are many "are you kidding me" moments, but if you don't enjoy them anyway, you're seriously watching the wrong movie.

The fight choreography is again top notch, and so are the ridiculous car stunts, including driving a luxury car from one skyscraper through the air into another. One criticism would be that the big battle at the end seems a bit too long, but maybe that's because you have been rattled with the action throughout.

Of course, the big item lurking in the back of your mind as you're watching all of this is, how are they going to do Paul Walker's sendoff? The ending was a masterfully done tribute that made me, uh, a bit misty ... along with the background song, it was a great way to deal with Paul's tragic death.

For go-for-broke stunts and this tribute, this should have a place in every action aficionado's library.

If you expect the Fast & Furious sequel Furious 7 to be over-the-top balls-to-the-wall action with frenetic and quick-cut fight sequences, explosions, big tough guys carrying on as big tough guys, explosions, lots of people yelling and screaming as they drive really fast in some hot hot hot cars that defy both physics and gravity, explosions, and glimpses of women dressed all shexshay as they dance and strut around cars and poolsand explosions, then you might be just a little disappointed to find out that there aren't as many explosions as you might have expected in this latest entry to the Paul Walker/ Vin Diesel action/adventure series that has really taken ahold of the gonzo action elements and run with them. It also manages to give a nice nod and touching send off to beloved star Paul Walker who passed away during filming; the end of the movie made me cry and I really didn't want to/ tried not to. Walker really will be missed.

Best of the fast and furious movies.  I have been a fan of fast and furious franchise since the beginning.  The stories,  action, cast chemistry just unmatchable.  There have been some real disappointments along the way such as Tokyo Drift and despite the intense action most recently, I really was not very happy with Fast and Furious 6 either but this one now with 7 more than made up for everything that was weak in some of the earlier films.  An incredible 'possible ending' to the franchise while  at the same time potentially leaving it open for a possible Fast and Furious 8; though I am in agreement along with most that this would probably be the best point to just go out  while on top. Any further movies would have to face the impossible challange of pushing the bar even higher.  Of course some of the action in this film was completely over the top just plain crazy and flat out unrealistic if you think about it but it still left you on the edge of your seat both cringing and laughing at the same time, was  just fantastic.  I am glad they decided to keep Paul's character in this movie verses just flat writing him out.  Having completed only initial shooting before he was gone, it would of been much easier to write him out completely for this movie.  If someone did not know what had happened, you would not know at least until the end.  They did such an incredibly excellent job between the CG, composite footage, and body stand in all used to recreate Paul and fimish out his character with the help of his brothers, just amazing job very well done.  Sure, there a few moments where if you knew already, you can tell a bit but if you didn't, I don't think someone would really notice and it was that seamless.  The movie was emotional, intense, action packed, intricate plot with more complex levels than some might realize pulling in all the elements which has made this franchise work well while taking everything to a new extreme.  Again some parts were over the top unrealistically crazy like the clean over the top tower jumps but it just added to the comedy and great entertainment which is what movies are really about anyway.  This is definitely one for the home collection and I will get this as soon as it is available. ADDENDUM:  I since received my extended edition Blueray and as expected is a must have for any home collection.  As a few have commented they could not see a difference between extended and regular editions, I did a simultaneous play of both side by side and found every edited moment.  Little to nothing is added to content but deleted scenes also on the Blueray give you some extra insight there.  What is changed is substantial on many of the action shots in most cases adding in extra seconds of footage re-editing and lengthening fight scenes.  The initial opening scene at the hospital is lengthened substantially and they worked in Dom's necklace in the extended version.  The after funeral car chicken scene is also lengthened as is the Abu Dabhi party cat fight scene.  The final Dom battle scene is another one.  The first conversation meeting Ramsey is re-edited very subtly and need side by side to notice the difference.  The rest is mostly adding seconds extra between cut points in most action scenes.  Very well done.

The BEST of the series.  It should really end here.  This movie was NON-STOP action.  And inventive, interesting action at that.  You are going to watch without blinking, with mouth wide open.  The dangerous predicaments are thrilling.  The hand-to-hand combat is insanely fun and complex.  The dialogue is well-written.  Nothing corny.  The plot twists and turns at such a fast pace, until its pile-up of a climax leaves you breathless.  Its resolution includes a touching tribute to Paul Walker (RIP) that breaks the wall between viewer, actor, and character.  Beautiful.

BUY IT NOW.  Trust me.  That rental fee will be a waste of money, because you are going to want to re-watch the spectacular stunts and combat in this baby!

Application of video-game-logic to a movie plot paired with large helpings of sentimental glurge. I guess action movie plots have always diverged from anything even vaguely possible in the real world and we all expect a certain amount of macho posturing and gallows humor as part of the scenery. But why all the whiny character interaction? Pretty much everything terrible comes from opera -- so I'll lay the blame there.

Maybe this movie would have been interesting if the creative team showed the slightest awareness that both the heroes and the main villain, played by Jason Statham, share the identical "family above all" ethos. As a statement about what happens when groups of super-powered sociopaths caring only for the welfare of their own families come to blows it could have had some merit. But hey, who am I kidding...

Furious 7
Fast & Furious began in 2001 as a movie involving an undercover cop in Los Angeles street racing but abandoned that setting for heists involving over-the-top action sequences and globe-trotting surveillance. For years the Fast & Furious series has been building a dense and complex mythology in modern Hollywood.

In the last film, Dominic Toretto (Vin Diesel) and his team defeated a British criminal named Owen Shaw (Luke Evans). In Fast & Furious 7, Deckard (Jason Statham), Shaws elder brother vows revenge. Deckard murders one of Torettos buddies and attacks his secret agent friend Luke Hobbs (Dwayne Johnson). He also blows up Torettos house and nearly kills Letty (Michelle Rodriguez), Brians wife who is also Torettos sister Mia (Jordana Brewster) and Brian and Mias young son. Wan states that this is what leads to Toretto vowing revenge on Deckard. This happens before Toretto and the rest of his crew, which also includes comic relief Roman (Tyrese Gibson) and computer expert Tej (Chris Ludacris Bridges), hook up with Mr. Nobody (Kurt Russell), a shadowy government operative to try and locate a tracking device.

Fast & Furious 7 does feel like the series farewell as the characters sullenly talk about taking one last ride together. Two different scenes are set in graveyards making it impossible to watch these moments and not think about Paul Walker who died in a tragic car accident in November 2013 before production had ended. Though Furious 7 delivers essential thrills, Walkers real life fate is on the audiences mind when his character, Brian OConner, hangs off the edge of a cliff from a crushed bus.

 The films midsection is most fascinating Disappointingly, Dwayne Johnson sits most of this chapter out.  Though he does make the most of his limited screen time.ng and thrilling to watch. The series ends with a wonderful tribute to Paul Walker. .  I would recommend the audience to watch the movie as it delivers plenty of loud cars and bad tempers.

This film has non-stop exciting action and all sorts of improbable but enjoyable situations. I felt that one regular cast member who has grown along with the rest of the cast as the series has evolved was dispensed with too readily, but otherwise a great film, outstanding cast, excellent cinematography and direction. This will definitely please fans of the Fast and Furious franchise and the hot rod, speed movie genre. This film has lots of fun and excitement and is OK for families with older kids to watch. There is no profanity that I can recall but lots of violence, although it has an ethereal quality. This is the most durable, bulletproof family of hot-rodders you will ever meet. Spellbinding special effects and touching tribute to the late Paul Walker, a talented artist who left us much too soon. Filmmaking gold.

Meh, I watched it, but will probably not ever watch it again. It's pretty much what you would expect from the F&F movies. I found the acting just terrible to the point where there were times where I had to cringe or roll my eyes after one of the actors said his/her line. I'm sure a lot of people gave it a good rating simply because of it being Paul's last movie. I can understand that if you were a hardcore fan of the series, and in truth I gave it 3 stars because I didn't think there was even one of the movies in this series that was worth more than that. Most or even all the driving is done in front of a green screen, which I detest. It's not even close to looking realistic at all.

This particular F&F movie was way over the top on all counts. Acting (seriously, it was horrible), special effects, the so-called driving, pretty much all the action scenes were just so over-blown it tended to ruin the movie for me. Sure it looked cool, but in the end it still ruined it for me because of just how unrealistic it was. These people defy certain death so many times if was just stupid.

Again, if you're a fan of this franchise, you'll most likely like this movie. Of all the actors in this series I think only Paul had any idea how to actually drive in real life. Which is really my biggest beet with a car-type movie. If you can't drive to begin with, don't get in the car because it is most definitely going to show.

I'm all for summer blockbuster movies playing fast and loose with realism, but this movie takes it to a WHOLE 'NUTHER LEVEL.  If you have godlike disbelief suspension and like crazy action that seems over the top even for a Saints Row game, this is probably a 5 for you.  Dwayne Johnson's character falls 4 stories ONTO a car with a 130lb woman on top of him and suffers only a fractured wrist (or that's what it seems like because he marches around the middle of a major metropolitan city carrying a mini-gun in the last scene), people drive off mountains and walk away from it with barely a scratch because "roll cage", so on and so forth...

It's entertaining, but I think the tragic death of Paul Walker is obscuring the painfully obvious flaws for most people.
These get better and better and I don't care what anyone says otherwise.
