"Furious 7" (2015) is directed by James Wan (The Conjuring, Insidious, Saw). This film is about Deckard Shaw's (Jason Satham) revenge for his comatose brother Owen Shaw as he tracks down the team of Dominic "Dom" Toretto, and Brian O'Conner. This film is an amazing blockbuster film that rivals the Marvel Avenger films for shear spectacular action. Cars are parachuted from cargo carriers, cars careen down mountain sides, one car even crashes through one skyscraper tower over into two other adjacent towers. Paul Walker died at the age of only 40 in a single vehicle accident before the filming was even half finished, however through rewrites and clever editing one would never have known it from the finished film. At the time of this writing it is interesting to note that this film has grossed more than films like Skyfall, and Lord of the Rings, and has moved into the top 4 position for all time earnings for a film just behind Marvel's The Avengers. This franchise just seems to get bett... Read more

I've got nothing but praise for this movie. Here we are, the seventh film in to a long running franchise and it just happens to be one of the best, one of the most unique and one of the most creative yet. Throughout the Fast and Furious series, the franchise has slowly grown from its humble beginnings as an undercover cop film that featured street racers and fast cars to something bigger and more bombastic with each new entry. No complaints from this guy either. I've loved the ride. Furious 7 to me is the most "blockbuster" film of the series to date. I honestly don't think this movie was any less exciting or "big" than any Marvel movie I've seen except for maybe Avengers and Winter Soldier. It was a huge movie, even more ambitious than the 6th which I thought was extremely ambitious in its own right. This has instantly become one of my favorites in the series easily on Par with #1 and #5 my other two favorites.

I also wanted to say what I thought about the Paul Walker situation. T... Read more

Before I get into the movie itself, I want to say a few things. Furious 7 was definitely one of my most anticipated movies of 2015, since I am a huge fan of the franchise. This was also a movie I went into with high expectations but was also curious to see how they would pull off this sequel given the fact that Paul Walker tragically passed away during the beginning of the movie's production. Now that I mentioned all of that, let's go over the movie itself. The story revolves around Deckard Shaw, who swears revenge on Dominic Toretto's group after the death of his brother Owen Shaw (the bad guy from the 6th movie). After Deckard Shaw kills a member of Toretto's group, Toretto gets his group back together and prepares for an action-packed fight towards Shaw. Was this sequel good? It wasn't just good..............IT WAS FANTASTIC!!!! I was genuinely surprised at how much fun I had with this movie and especially with how they managed to film this sequel without Paul Walker to continue his role as Brian O'Connor. If you don't know, Paul's brothers Caleb and Cody were used to complete his scenes. Jason Statham was definetly perfect as the antagonist and watching the rest of the main cast members continue their roles as their characters was awesome to watch. The movie has constant moments of well-directed action sequences but also has some moments of humor and surprisingly, a few moments of drama. The one thing that defined this movie is of course the final scene. I won't give away the ending for those who haven't seen it, but let's just say that your eyes will more likely pour a lot of tears. Overall, Furious 7 was an outstanding movie with a perfect way to honor one of the franchise's most well-beloved actors, Paul Walker. If you haven't seen this movie, you are missing out on a phenomenal action movie!!!!

Now, don't get me wrong.  Paul Walker was a nice guy who did a lot of nice things, but he wasn't exactly a groundbreaking actor.  Same can be said for anyone else in this franchise.  Furious 7 takes this franchise to a whole new level of ridiculous.  2F2F and Tokyo Drift aside (dont even get me started on how bad those were), I have been a huge fan of this series from the beginning, and I am usually at the theater opening night, ticket in hand.  The plots are never plausible, but the films are (almost) always entertaining and action-packed.  This one was neither of those things.

There was so much unnecessary dialog in this film, much of it being the basic message of all that matters is family.  If youve seen ANY of the FNF movies starring the core cast (Diesel, Walker, Brewster, Rodriguez), then you know this theme is the driving force and trigger for all of each plot.  If you didn't watch one through six, you're probably not going to watch number seven.  So why shove it down the audiences throats for two hours and seventeen minutes?  It got old after the eleventh or twelfth super-sappy, way-too-quiet touching conversation.  I get it.  You love each other.  Moving on.

The action scenes were well beyond over the top.  At one point, we have Dom and Brian in a car with no breaks jumping from one skyscraper to another via driving through the mirrored plate glass windows at high speeds.  Um, no.  Maybe one for the sake of a great action scene, but we really need to push it out to two jumps?  Really?  You took it from unrealistic but good for action to so far out of the realm of possibility that it just came off as laughable.

Additionally, the scene where Dom is standing up on top of the parking garage, stomps his foot, and the concrete crumbles right in front of him as though he were some sort of titan.  Hes not.  His one little stomp is not going to be the thing that causes the three-foot-deep piece of concrete to crumble.

Lets not even get into the fight scene between Dwayne Johnson and Jason Statham (I love Statham but The Rock would squish that man with one good squeeze), the almost cartoonish first car chase scene, or the fact that the cameos in the movie served absolutely no purpose.

Plus, the ending made NO SENSE.  None.  Im just saying, you guys could have spent a little bit more time in the writers room.

Disappointed.  Very, very disappointed.

I will warn you, bad movie or not, watching and knowing that's the last time we'd see Paul Walker WILL bring tears to your eyes.  The writers tried very hard to make this installment in the franchise an emotion-fueled hell ride.  Hints of the emotion they were going for are certainly there, but for the most part, it just fell short.  I'm sad to see the end of this particular era.  I just wish they had given Walker a better executed farewell.
Don't miss this one. A CLASSIC. More action beyond belief ...wow and omg... I loved it.
Absolutely an amazing movie. The dedication to Paul walker put me to tears. Phenomenal movie went to the movies 3 times just to watch this movie.
best one

If theres one thing to want from a Fast and Furious film, its outrageous vehicle-fueled action. On that front, this seventh film delivers amply, then still heaps even more on top just for the heck of it. Its robust budget is on full display as all manner of cars are repeatedly raced, flown and destroyed in the most outlandish feats. The characters are now equally superpowered to survive such fantastic stunts unharmed, often engaging in hand-to-hand combat which wouldve killed a regular mortal twenty-times over. A typical action scene from this movie would be the glorious finale to another inferior film, yet F7 is not only happy to give the viewer such climactic moments, but then it cant help itself but as to immediately top such moments in its incessant quest for the greatest thrills. With a wide cast of characters at its disposal, the scenes often crosscut back and forth to deliver all manner of excitement and thrills simultaneously a magical world where fistfights, car chases and shootouts are all happening everywhere at the same time.

Sure, the dialog can be clunky, the acting middling, and both logic and reality are often non-existent to explain its dumbed-down plot. But the heart is good enough, the score is quite strong, and the cinematography and effects are all visually top-notch. So when the film also features several of the decades best action scenes in one movie, theres no reason a true action junkie wouldnt enjoy this filmmaking zenith of vehicular carnage - a glorious ode to speed, explosions and all manners of violence.
Rip paul walker

"Furious 7" (2015) is directed by James Wan (The Conjuring, Insidious, Saw). This film is about Deckard Shaw's (Jason Satham) revenge for his comatose brother Owen Shaw as he tracks down the team of Dominic "Dom" Toretto, and Brian O'Conner. This film is an amazing blockbuster film that rivals the Marvel Avenger films for shear spectacular action. Cars are parachuted from cargo carriers, cars careen down mountain sides, one car even crashes through one skyscraper tower over into two other adjacent towers. Paul Walker died at the age of only 40 in a single vehicle accident before the filming was even half finished, however through rewrites and clever editing one would never have known it from the finished film. At the time of this writing it is interesting to note that this film has grossed more than films like Skyfall, and Lord of the Rings, and has moved into the top 4 position for all time earnings for a film just behind Marvel's The Avengers. This franchise just seems to get better and better.

Dominic Toretto (Vin Diesel) and his tight-knit gang of street racers must battle the brother of a defeated nemesis and rescue a software genius from terrorists. Holy Christ! That was fun. Who knew James Wan (Saw, Insidious, The Conjuring) could direct such an awe inspiring action flick. Sure he directed the great revenge film Death Sentence with Kevin Bacon, but he just topped it with this entry to the F&F series. Without a doubt the best one so far. Not only is it the best, it's also the most over-the-top, unrealistic and corny one yet. That's what makes it so special. You have the regulars Vin Diesel, Paul Walker, Michelle Rodriguez, Jordana Brewster etc. And they brought back Dwayne Johnson (The Rock) & Jason Statham and added the fabulous Rhonda Rousey (small cameo fighting Michelle R). The most surprising addition is certainly Kurt Russell. The man is a legend in my household and I grew up watching him in Escape from New York and The Thing. Thankfully it looks like Kurt is on the comeback trail. He has the awesome sounding horror/western 'Bone Tomahawk' coming up, and of course 'The Hateful Eight' directed by Quentin Tarantino. Glad to see him again! I enjoyed the film immensely and the fast pace action. Paul Walker will certainly be missed. His brother finished some of his scenes for him and the ending is a real tear jerker. Please go and watch the film if you're a fan of Paul Walker, his memory is well represented in the film.
don't have to review, it's great before I get it.

When THE FAST AND THE FURIOUS was released in 2001, despite becoming a sensation and catapulting leads Vin Diesel and Paul Walker into certified stardom and leading-man status (and for a time, gave director Rob Cohen a bit of a career), it didn't seem like it was exactly the kind of film that would launch a franchise that has lasted for 14 years and giving us seven films. Although in hindsight, it totally is the kind of film that could launch a franchise and a rabid fanbase; it has super-cool leads, super-cool cars, super-hot women, super-intense action, and a bare minimum of plot. Even when the series began to falter with its less-than-interesting entries like TOKYO DRIFT and the fourth film, simply titled FAST AND FURIOUS, it knew that it had to reinvent itself as a true action film franchise. The audience was becoming sick of the constant meaningless racing scenes and wanted something more well action-y, like gunplay and what-not. That gave us FAST FIVE, a balls-out pedal-to-the-medal action film that not only introduced intrepid manhunter Hobbs (Dwayne No Longer The Rock Johnson) to the series but became one of my favorite surprises of 2011. Then came FAST AND FURIOUS 6, which, while entertaining and crazy, was maybe a little too dark for me. Now, in what should be the franchises final film for various reasons but most assuredly won't be (because MONEY), comes FURIOUS 7, the franchises most psychotic and chaotic entry that benefits from some inventive set pieces, some genuine emotional content, and a check your brain at the door aloofness that comes only with absolute confidence that the fans are going to be blown away.

The film opens seemingly moments after the pre-credits ending of 6 where Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham, really relishing the hell out of playing a proper villain) is at the bedside of his comatose younger brother Owen (the previous installments big bad, Luke Evans) and swears vengeance. As he leaves the hospital room, the halls and exterior of the building are LITTERED with bodies of guards and doctors, indicating that Deckard is not a man to be trifled with. Next, we cut back to back in Los Angeles where Hobbs is working late at his office and Deckard sneaks in to gather intel on the crew that hurt his baby brother. An abbreviated fight ensues where Hobbs in blown out of a fifth-floor window, lands on the roof of a car, and still survives. Meanwhile, Dominic Torretto (Vin Diesel) is still assisting Letty (Michelle Rodriguez) in recovering her memory prior to her demise in the fourth film. Still encountering some PTSD, she leaves Dom to try to find what she lost on her own. Meanwhile, Brian OConnor (Paul Walker) is adjusting to life without a mission and being a dad in a minivan taking his son to school. He and his wife Mia (Jordana Brewster) are still (?) living with Dom in his house as Dom finds a package from Japan and gets a call from Deckard, who is just leaving the post-credits sequence from 6 where he has just killed Han (Sung King), and the package blows up Doms house.  A brief connection with Hobbs leaves Dom with the information that the elder Shaw was a British Special Forces soldier that became too extreme for them and has been in hiding for six years until now and is seeking revenge. Dom and Brian reunite with Tej (Chris Ludacris Bridges), Roman (Tyrese Gibson) and Letty to meet Mr. Nobody (Kurt Russell), a super-secret spook with a specific agenda; get Dom and his crew to rescue a hacker called Ramsey (Nathalie Emmanuel, GAME OF THRONES) who has designed a piece of software called Gods Eye that can hack into any intenet-connected camera on the planet and find any person anywhere. Shes been kidnapped by an international terrorist Jakande (Djimon Hounsou) and is in transit. If Dom can retrieve Gods Eye for Mr. Nobody, he can use it to find Shaw and preferably, kill him.

This leads them on an international game of cat-and-mouse where Dom and crew need to save Ramsey, who is being transported in Jakandes HEAVILY armed convoy in Azerbaijan, where naturally, Shaw is waiting for them. After her mostly-successful rescue, they need to retrieve the program thats been installed into a Jordanian princes supercar in Abu Dhabi, where Shaw is waiting for them. They escape by the skin of their teeth, plug in the Gods Eye and track Shaw who is waiting for them with his new friends, namely Jakandes team. Again, barely escaping, but losing the Maguffin ahem Gods Eye, they retreat to their home turf where the final confrontation will occur across the streets, skies, and rooftops of the City of Angels.

James Wan (the director of SAW and DEATH SENTENCE) takes over for Justin Lin, who directed the previous three films, and turns the crazy up to eleven with sequences that are so astonishingly and ridiculously absurd, even LOONEY TUNES animators would have seen this film and said, Dial it down a notch, man. Yes, its that crazy. The whole finale with the helicopter, the drone and the cars is what Michael Bay must see when hes on LSD, and yet, because its a FAST AND FURIOUS film, it works. Its just SO over the top that you either jump right on board or you just forget it and go see something else. The skydiving cars sequence alone is so inspired yet so defiant of logic, you have a feeling that the filmmakers looked at a statue of Isaac Newton and blew it up with a nitrous tank. Then theres the triple jump across divisions of the Burj Khalifa that is just you get the point. And of course, the film does fit the franchises required quota of 12,000 camera shots taken from a womans butt/crotch level. So don't you worry, male teen and pre-teen audience members; you get your moneys worth here.

There are times where the film insults you, though. I can suspend my disbelief only so long, but when Paul Walker squares off against Tony Jaa (of ONG BAK and THE PROTECTOR), who plays Jakandes lead henchman, there is no way on earth that Paul Walker wins that fight. Not at all. Its literally like if you had a film from the 70s that was unearthed where Robert Redford fought Bruce Lee AND WON. Nope. It just doesnt happen. And the same thing happened in this film as it did in the last film: Michelle Rodriguez fights a series of female MMA champions AND WINS. Last film, it was Gina Carano, and this film, its Ronda Rousey. NOPE.

Of course, as par for the course, no one in the cast of FURIOUS 7 is exactly doing their career-best performance, but they all seem to be having a good time, particularly Statham and Russell, who really sinks his teeth into this role and has almost too much fun with it. Hes far too genial for the head of a super-secret black-ops organization, and that leads me to another point. While the whole idea of the Gods Eye program falling into the hands of the US Government gave me some thoughts on how the film was going to treat that concept, I forgot that this is a FAST AND FURIOUS film, and that it would naturally go nowhere as far as socio-political commentary would be concerned, so don't worry about being confronted with anything intellectually challenging here.

One of the things this film lacked from the previous few entries were some positive steps in the gender politics arena as well. Serious ass-kicking women like Gal Gadot, Gina Carano and Elsa Pataky were introduced and made part of the team for a while. This film gets Letty back on the side of the angels, but sidelines Pataky to about 60 seconds of screen-time and Jordana Brewster is reduced to merely a fretting wife and mother. And though this film does give ample screen-time to Nathalie Emmanuel and Rodriguez, it doesnt really pave the way forward for women in action cinema as the last few films were trying to do.

All this is still kind of moot though, because the world of FAST AND FURIOUS clearly belongs to the Y chromosome half of the population. Im not saying that women shouldnt or don't like it because they clearly do, but this isn't that franchise and it never has been. Whether thats good or bad seems like it should matter, but it doesnt really, because, and Ill say it one last time its a FAST AND FURIOUS film. No one came in here trying to change the world; they just wanted to bring some entertainment to the masses. And they succeeded. And I'm not trying to say that in a snobbish way; I've seen ALL of these films, and for the most part, I enjoy them.

I would be extremely remiss if I didn't take a moment to comment on the tragic death of Paul Walker. He has always been a fine performer even if he seemed a little wooden at times, and his connection to the fans of this franchise is indeed powerful. The tribute this film pays to him is quite moving even if the moments of CGI Paul Walker are a little distracting. I cried a little. He'll certainly be missed.

While FURIOUS 7 won't be a serious contender for my year-end Best Of list, its certainly a lot of fun, even if while you're watching it, you can feel people like Bill Nye and Neil Degrasse-Tyson having conniptions.

Let me start by saying I am a fan of this franchise....having said that, there were a couple of flops (2 Fast 2 Furious & Tokyo Drift). I would, however, suggest if you aren't familiar with the franchise familiarize yourself with the last two movies first (at the very least).

I was skeptical going into this movie because it is difficult to make a series like this without losing the originality. But I would say, no matter what your movie type...if you're a movie buff this is definitely at worth seeing.

It is easy. This movie gets 5 stars if you like the series.
And it gets one star if you just like movies.
I mean do not misunderstand me, it is a fan to watch action movie,
with great cars, great guns, great bad lines, and a lot of wild driving
and unrealistic scenes, which are kind of natural in the series.
Still, there are some scenes here that go over the top, unique in
cinema history (remember that when you watch the skyscraper scene).
But once again they over do it (eg they even include a drone in a scene)
and that is why there are those who like the series and a lot who don't
There is no need to talk plot since no one really cares if there is one.
Of course, like we all know this is the last movie in the series that Paul Walker did,
and to that extent, the necessary respect is given to him in this movie.

So again, this is a movie for those who like the series and for those who like
action movies with a lot of hyperbolic stuff in them

This time it ain't just about being fast. Brian (Walker) has moved on from his fast lifestyle and is settling into fatherhood. When the brother of an old enemy shows up for revenge Brian, Dom (Diesel) and the rest of the gang are thrown back into the furious world they have come to know. This is a movie that is pretty much review proof. Being the 7th movie in a series it already has a bulit in audience, as well as those that want to see this because its Paul Walkers last movie. I have to start off by saying that I have never been a fan of these movies. They are just too over the top and cheesy for me to fully get into. All that said I do have to admit that this is the 2nd best in the series I think (after Fast 5). The stunts are very over the top, but not as bad as the last one. The real downfall of this movie is Vin Diesels dialogits so bad. The one liners made me laugh rather than having the dramatic effect he was going for. Again though this is review proof and you will either see it because you have seen the rest, or you won't for the same reason. I will say that the ending was very nice and really closed the movie (and series) up nicelybut they are making another one, because god forbid they end this. Overall, fans of the series will love this. I liked this more than I expected and I thought it was the 2nd best in the series. I give it a B.

I first saw the fast and the furious when it first came out in theaters when I was a teenager. I was on vacation with a bunch of friends at the beach and we all went and saw it. I have been a fan of this franchise ever sense and have seen all of them. When I heard Paul Walker passed away I literally cried because I am a huge fan and I wasn't sure if I could handle seeing this film. But when it came out a bunch of my friends and I went and saw it. I am so glad I did!! I cried from the beginning, then stopped to enjoy the thrill of the story and action (which kept me on the edge of my seat) and then balled again at the end. The writers, director, and everyone involved in the making of this film did a beautiful job honoring not only the life of Paul but also the legacy and friendships he leaves behind. Anyone who says anything bad about this film is to be ignored because even if you set aside the passing of Paul, this still would have been a top notch, action packed, thrill ride! Loved every second of it and I am purchasing it right away!

This is way, way, way over the top, but consistently fun and enjoyable. Nice to see so many top stars crammed into an exciting film, and any movie where Jason Statham faces off against both Vin Diesel and Dwayne Johnson is a must. Contains one of the best lines in movie history: Leti: "Did you bring the cavalry?" Hobbs: "Woman, I am the cavalry."

If you expect the Fast & Furious sequel Furious 7 to be over-the-top balls-to-the-wall action with frenetic and quick-cut fight sequences, explosions, big tough guys carrying on as big tough guys, explosions, lots of people yelling and screaming as they drive really fast in some hot hot hot cars that defy both physics and gravity, explosions, and glimpses of women dressed all shexshay as they dance and strut around cars and poolsand explosions, then you might be just a little disappointed to find out that there aren't as many explosions as you might have expected in this latest entry to the Paul Walker/ Vin Diesel action/adventure series that has really taken ahold of the gonzo action elements and run with them.  It also manages to give a nice nod and touching send off to beloved star Paul Walker who passed away during filming; the end of the movie made me cry and I really didn't want to/ tried not to.  Walker really will be missed.

Plot: Following directly from Fast 6 (not a bad idea to watch that before you view this one, but also not necessary for new viewers) Walkers Brian OConnor is trying to adjust to the sedate role of dad in the minivan crowd and Diesels Dominic Toretto is hanging out at in the barrio when they receive an explosive delivery from baddie Deckard Shaw (played by an always visceral Jason Statham) who is a black ops English badass who is looking to take revenge on the people who killed his brother (see the aforementioned Fast 6 for relevant history).  What transpires is Deckards almost success and it prompts Dom and Brian to reconvene their crew one last time and take the fight to Deckard.  Along the way they get the help from a covert U.S. Special Forces team that they have to help in order to get what they want.  You can expect the U.S. team to double-cross them, of course.  The F&F crew (or family as they refer to each other) go on a globe-trotting mission before finally returning to their L.A. stomping grounds for the final showdown with Deckard and other baddies.  In the end not all of the family will be coming back

I have been careful not to give away any major spoilers in my summary, but there may be some (mis)leading elements there.  What I will say is that this entry continues the trend of the series to pack a walloping amount within the film and include new stars even if in essentially cameo roles.  Fans of mega-MMA star Ronda Rousey will get a brief glimpse of her in an action scene that I felt was unnecessary and didn't showcase her potential (while she wasn't a stand-out in Expendables 3 she did work well within that movie).  Grizzled action anti-hero Kurt Russel shows up as a kinda corny Special Forces division head who can make things happen.  Tony Jaa also shows up as a superior hand-to-hand combatant and its a pleasure to watch his fluid and creative choreography and movements.  Relative newcomer and new addition to the F&F family is Ramsey (played by Brit Nathalie Emmanuel who is cute as a button but not given anything substantial to do other than look goodwhich she does.) but the real steal here is Statham.  Early on in the movie he has a physical showdown with Hobbs (Dwayne The Rock Johnson) that turns out to be a fun fight and establishes him as a worthy villain but the movie also sets it up for us to suspect that well only be seeing him again at the end.  Fortunately for us this is not so as Statham routinely (and unexplainedly) turns up throughout the movie to hunt down and harry our heroes.  Hes a real pain in their necks and (spoiler) you don't actually see him dieso.sequel?  I wouldnt mind seeing him turn up again.  At any rate there are some ridiculous action sequences like cars driving down a forested mountainside, some nicely staged fights like Walker versus Jaa or Statham versus the Rock, surprise relationship reveals like Letty (Michelle Rodriguez) and Doms (censored), and lots of unexplained happenstance.  Par for the course.

My main complaint about the movie is the editing.  They give us interesting visual angles and some fun camera tricks but Im not sure that theres a camera shot that ever stays on track for more than 4-5 seconds!  This drives me nuts.  This must feel like what it is to have visual ADHD.  At times it can help create excitement or tension but when its overly used it becomes distracting (and sometimes disorienting).  This, in combo with the movies actual length (running about 2 hours and 10 minutes before end credits), makes the movie feel longer than it should.  If you liked, really liked, or loved the previous two installments to the F&F franchise then you should at least enjoy the movie.  I think that it provides a nice stopping point to the franchise, is a smart and reverent way to bow out deceased star Walker, but 5 & 6 were ultimately better and cleaner films than this busy and buzzy clocker that is all kinds of summer popcorn crazy.

If you expect the Fast & Furious sequel Furious 7 to be over-the-top balls-to-the-wall action with frenetic and quick-cut fight sequences, explosions, big tough guys carrying on as big tough guys, explosions, lots of people yelling and screaming as they drive really fast in some hot hot hot cars that defy both physics and gravity, explosions, and glimpses of women dressed all shexshay as they dance and strut around cars and poolsand explosions, then you might be just a little disappointed to find out that there aren't as many explosions as you might have expected in this latest entry to the Paul Walker/ Vin Diesel action/adventure series that has really taken ahold of the gonzo action elements and run with them.  It also manages to give a nice nod and touching send off to beloved star Paul Walker who passed away during filming; the end of the movie made me cry and I really didn't want to/ tried not to.  Walker really will be missed.

It took me just about 3 years of Patients to see this movie I couldn't wait for it to come out. I followed every social media post they had for this movie, to tell you how much is done and what have they finished. The animation is just too respectable because most of the film was produced by CGI technology. All of the animations and stunts grab your attention through the whole movie. Some of the stunts that took my Attention and made me retell them to others were, when Vin diesel raced his car on the middle of a Skyscraper and zoomed out the window while jumping to the next Skyscraper and going right though it and surprising everyone with his entrance though the window that was 100 story tall. It was about fourteen years ago that the original Fast and the Furious was made, and since then I have seen all of the hit franchise. Like its predecessors, Furious Seven is a fun movie with a lot of over-the-top action sequences (in which cars can fly!), but this time it has an unexpectedly emotional ending, especially for the fans of the series.

The story is simple. One character played by Jason Statham, seeking revenge for his severely injured brother, threatens the peaceful life of Dominic (Vin Diesel) and Brian (Paul Walker). To fight back the new enemy, Dominic and the crew agree to accept the offer of Mr. Nobody (Kurt Russell), leader of a covert ops team, and to obtain a computer program God's Eye that can locate anyone almost instantly.

With the franchises signature stunt work including outrageous car action, Furious Seven offers lots of action set-pieces, but the most impressive part of the film is its conclusion, where the filmmakers say goodbye to Paul Walker in a fitting way.

If you have not seen any of the franchise, probably Furious Seven would not be the best starting point. You would think characters are too many (and they are), and some episodes seem pointless. For anyone who has been following the series for years, Furious Seven would be a great ride that is both enjoyable and poignant.

Theatrical review. Possible spoilers. In what I expect will be one of the biggest movies of the year, the series may also have produced the best chapter yet. This edition picks up close to where the last one ended. After dispatching bad guy, Owen Shaw (Luke Evans) in the earlier film we see his bad-ass older brother, Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham) pledge revenge on Dom Toretto (Vin Diesel) and his crew beginning with his government accomplice Hobbs (Dwayne Johnson).

We know that Shaw isn't to be trifled with early on as he and Hobbs go mano y mano with only Hobbs being sent to the hospital. Shaw, having hacked Hobbs's computer has the names and locations of everyone and begins his vengeful killing spree in Tokyo and almost gets Dom, his sister Mia (Jordana Brewster), his new brother-in-law, Brian (Paul Walker) and their toddler, with a bomb. After this happens, Dom gets that look in his eye and vows to go after Shaw.

In a secondary plotline, a secretive quasi-government unit headed by "Mr. Nobody" (a scene stealing Kurt Russell), wants Dom and his crew to rescue a tech-genius named Ramsey (Nathalie Emmanuel from "Game of Thrones"). She's developed a system that can track anyone in the world by hacking into traffic cameras, computers, cell phones and any and all electronic devices and using sophisticated facial recognition software. If the crew can pull it off, Dom is promised access in order to track down Shaw.

This is all just an excuse to kick-start a couple of hours of non-stop action sequences, the best of which is Dom, Brian, Letty (Michelle Rodrigues) who still has memory loss, Roman (Tyrese Gibson) and Tej (Ludacris) sky-dive...along with their cars...onto an otherwise obscure mountain highway in Azerbaijan. This undetected approach allows them to find and rescue Ramsey, but only after a series of remarkably staged and executed stunts involving cars, stunt drivers and the actors.

Unlike previous F & F films, I found these to be tension-filled in addition to the action. Djimon Hounsou shows up here as the leader of the group who kidnapped Ramsey, along with Asian action star Tony Jaa who has a fearsome fight with Brian in this sequence and later in the film. All of this nonsense clears the way for some even more ridiculous, but downright brilliant scenes shot in Abu Dhabi where Dom launches a $3.5 million super car through a series of glassy skyscrapers.

Eventually the gang returns to L. A. with Shaw and Jakande (Hounsou) hot on their trail with the "God's Eye" device in their pocket. In addition to some terrific action sequences and well-choreographed fights, the movie concludes with an emotional send off to Walker who died in the middle of shooting the film in 2013. While it plays within the confines of the script, it is also an obvious fond farewell from the hearts of the actors. Yeah, it's authentic and it's touching.
Best one yet!!!!!!!!! Too bad about Paul walker,he was a great actor. This movie rocks and has great action scenes.

I went to go see this movie on the third of April I was expecting it to be boring and s***. Turned out to be better then the other fast and the furious movies. The ending was a teary eyed I cried at the ending. so much love that day R.I.P Paul Walker and I already preordered the movie can't wait for it.

Best Furious to date - we watched this opening night, and have watched every one.  This is the best one so far - great car scenes, death defying stunts, over the top villains and hot girls/cars/guys - what's not to love?  This is a great guy movie - it is also a great girls night out movie, and a great date movie - it truly has something for everyone.

This has everything you expect from the Furious franchise, but an even bigger focus on family.  The funny thing is, after watching this, it made me think a lot of the Disney animated movie Lilo & Stitch :).

I loved the addition of Kurt Russell, as well as Jason Statham, who plays pretty much the same character he always plays, just on the villain side this time.

Amazing what they did with this movie from a continuity and filming perspective given the timing of the situation with Paul Walker, all I can say is wow, and there has to be some sort of award for this movie this year.  The tribute at the end was extremely moving, and if you are a Paul Walker fan, you might find yourself welling up just a bit (or more).  Made me think a bit about my friends as well.

So go have a great time and don't miss this one!  If you haven't seen the others in the franchise, make sure to see what you've missed - it helps make the story that much more interesting.  But regardless, it is a hell of a ride!

Just saw this movie tonight after waiting so long. Fantastic! Definitely created by the actors using their hearts 100%. You can feel what they each have gone through after the tragedy that's taken Paul Walker's life. He surely is missed by all. Well done, exciting, top notch film! The action is incredible!!! Nothing like it out there has even been done! Action action action!!! The story was fantastic and pulled together most of the movies very well! Really well done! I'm in awe as well as my eyes are so swollen from crying my heart out. The ending... made perfect!!! RIP Paul Walker ~ you are so deeply missed and loved.
Nice

I personally love this series of movies, they have come along way over the years and grown Hugely into a massive epic saga of action movies that don't stop coming, each time bigger action and bigger cast, this one has to top them all in terms of stunts, loads of great action to sink your teeth into, this time around Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham) seeks revenge of the death of his brother Owen Shaw (Luke Evans) from furious 6, we get a fantastic open sequence that introduces Jason's villain and a fine addition to the cast he is, Deckard is a wrecking ball of destruction and the rest of the team have to stop him, Dwayne Johnson is great as usual as Hobbs, Vin Diesel, Paul Walker, Michelle Rodriguez, Jordana Brewster, Tyrese Gibson, Ludacris, Elsa Pataky are all back playing their specific parts, plus now the addition of Kurt Russell and Tony Jaa (very under-used though) and the smoking hot Ronda Rousey (Expendables 3) the visual effects are top notch as you would expect, especially of course the Paul walker scenes that were finished digitally look amazing, Paul walker gets a fantastic send off or a parting of the team ending which was nice, as he drives off into the light we get a nice compilation of flashback footage from all the previous movies! The movie also features a cameo from Lucas Black which is good as it ties Tokyo drift officially tighter into the loop of the whole saga, if your a fan of the series certainly check it out you cant go wrong, every second is furiously awesome!
I love this movie

This is a very emotional movie. It is the best Fast and Furious movie so far. I love how the movie emphasized that family is very important. The last part of the movie made me cry. We know Paul will no longer be with us, but the movie made us think that Paul will still be there somewhere taking care of his family. I have read blogs about Fast and Furious 8 and they say that there will also be Fast 9, and 10. Im looking forward to watch it in the future. :)
I vote this movie for movie of the year at the 2016 mtv movie awards. One of the best movies I saw this year!

This movie is by far the BEST one in the franchise. I almost cried at the end when they did the very emotional tribute to Paul Walker. Watching those flashbacks from the other films is what made me want to purchase the other sequels. I heard that they might make 3 more sequels. I really hope they do. I honestly think that Paul would've liked that. RIP PAUL WALKER!!!! WE MISS YOU VERY MUCH!!!!!

While Furious 6 was over the top fun, this one goes too far with one ridiculous and unbelievable scene after another. When you can no longer suspend disbelief, it becomes dumb. The cliches ran rampant and I could not wait for the movie to end. (And I normally love big action movies).

I'm not sure who the target market for this movie is, but I'm guessing 12 to 16 year old males?  Most of the movie was entertaining, altho incredibly unbelievable--and I don't mean that in a good way.  The stunts and special effects get 5 stars, such as they were, while the storyline and acting get 2 stars at best.  So, I'm awarding 3 stars overall.  That being said, after you've produced 6 movies of this type, what are you going to do to make #7 stand out?  The over-used clichs and "cliff-hanger" events were so predictable, I could have written this script.  The actors put a lot of effort into grunting out their dialogue--when there was dialogue.  One-to-five-word sentences were the norm.  But, hey, do you really go see this movie for the great acting and witty banter?  The wife said she really enjoyed it because of all the cute guys...  Oh well, I'm pretty sure I will never watch this movie again.  I probably wouldn't have watched it in the first place, but I got (2) "free" vouchers from Castrol when I did my last oil change for my car.  Bottom line, it's probably worth watching once if you are a F&F fan, and a "maybe" if you are not.  I certainly could have lived the rest of my life without ever seeing it.  Our tickets for IMAX were $12.25 each (the vouchers were for up to $13 each).  I also could have waited for this one to come out on DVD and paid about $3 for a rental the whole family could watch together.  Truthfully, I enjoyed the 30 minutes of previews prior to this movie more than this movie.  How this movie has 4.5+ stars out of 5 stars currently is beyond me...  Maybe I'm just out of touch...  LOL, well, regardless, there's my opinion, for whatever it's worth to you.  Thanks for reading.
Awesome, Amazing, Exciting. Two thumps way up.

I have seen the movie in Teather, it's great!
I am buying it for Paul!

Im not sure when exactly it happened (probably around 2011s Fast Five, thanks Dwayne), but the Fast & Furious Franchise quickly became a serious guilty pleasure of mine.

Since moving from a street racing-based franchise to an Avengers-esq gathering of franchise heroes with a touch of Oceans 11-style high-end heisting, I haven't been able to escape these films. Fast Five and Fast & Furious 6 mark two of the most insanely enjoyable action movies of the decade so far, so it goes without saying that I  like many others of you  was very much looking forward to Furious 7 for Summer 2014.

Unfortunately, however, life had another plan for us all. With the tragic  and ironic  death of star Paul Walker in a high-speed car crash during a production break, Universal Pictures, and the films cast (lead by star and producer Vin Diesel) had to take a long step away from the film, and really decide if they wanted to finish it  and also  if they could finish the film.

Furious 7 finally hit theaters last week, and Im pleased to say that while the final film doesnt entirely hit the highs of Fast Five and Fast & Furious 6, the end result is another insane action film, filled with heart as it sends off one of its key players.

Set shortly after Fast & Furious 6  which in and of itself is sort of followed by Fast & Furious: Tokyo Drift, the third film in the franchise  Furious 7 thrusts us into the world of Deckard Shaw (action legend Jason Statham). Shaw is the brother of Owen Shaw  the villain of the last installment  who is out for revenge, aimed directly at Dominic Torretto (Diesel) and his makeshift family, the stars of this franchise. He kills off Asian racer Han (as shown in the post-credits scene of Fast & Furious 6), he puts Hobbs (Dwayne The Rock Johnson) in the hospital, and is aiming to take the rest of the crew out.

This of course worries Dom, as he is obsessed with two things: cars, and the protection of his family, which has become a bit more official with his sister Mias (Jordana Brewster) involvement with ex-cop Brian OConnor (Paul Walker). The two even have a child now, which means that Brian cant quite get called into as many insane adventures anymore. Add that Doms love interest Letty (Michelle Rodriguez) is still dealing with the amnesia she had when she came back from the dead  yes, thats a thing  and Doms got a lot on his plate this installment.

This plot  somewhat straight forward, pitting Dom vs. Shaw in a battle to protect everything he knows and loves  is further complicated with three additions: (1) a shadowy government organization lead by Mr. Nobody (Kurt Russell), who wishes to have Dom help them find (2) a hacker named Ramsey (Game of Thrones Nathalie Emmanuel), who is being held captive by (3) a terrorist group lead by Mose Jakande (Djimon Hounsou), who wishes to have control of an observation software called the Gods Eye, which allows the user to monitor every and all camera, cellphone communication and satelite to track anyone in the world. They tie this together as Mr. Nobody offering Dom the chance to easily find Shaw in return for completing the rescue mission, but as you can see  its three additional plot points that muddy a pretty straightforward story.

Perhaps this is due to the off screen tragedy  with the movie only half complete at the time of Walkers passing, director James Wan (Insidious), Vin Diesel and writer Chris Morgan worked hard to pull the movie back together and deliver something that both came together and and served as a farewell to Walkers character.

For the most part  they succeeded.

The action remains intense and insane, featuring the same eye-popping stunts and mind-bending physics fans have come to expect in the franchise. Since the shift of the franchise after Fast Five, Furious 7 again delivers an Avengers-esq gathering of leads who do the impossible. The action peaks somewhat early with a jaw dropping smash-and-grab sequence where the team aims to rescue Ramsey, which involves a mountain side race, mounted turrets, a giant armored bus, and (of course) a group of cars being dropped from an airplane. Wan, who is new to the franchise, shows himself an adept director of action, shooting very unique hand-to-hand combat with dizzying camera work, but has the steady hand to allow the vehicular action to breathe, letting fans take in how crazy the creators of this franchise are to do what they do with (mostly) real cars completing the stunts.

I could mention a few flaws of the film, namely that with Han and Giselle gone (and Hobbs sidelined), the cast doesnt feel as fun, and how new additions Tony Jaa and Rhonda Rousey basically just serve the film to star in some visceral fight sequences (which in Rouseys case, may be best  shes an incredible fighter, but not so great at the line readsstill love you, girl!). But the fact is, in the face of incredible adversity, Wan, Diesel and the entire Furious family pulled this film together. Sometimes it definitely feels held together by gum, spit and hope, but it remains another immensely enjoyable installment in arguably one of the finest franchises going today.

Besides, Furious 7 deserves all of your money for finally proving one thing: Iggy Azalea causes PTSD.
Everything about this movie was perfect. The ending truly touched me and made me emotional. #fastfurious for life

All the people who gave it 1-3 stars is a shame to me your not Fast and Furious Hardcore Fans Yes the First one was great but to me I think that all of them are just as good if not better. Best most greatest action movie saga ever made. The ending ended so great and heart warming then any other movie. Due to the fact that Paul really left us. They knew how to end the movie very well. It made me cry in happy tears. Everyone will miss his company. Paul is a brother to everyone... fast family...forever.
I'd pay to see this in theaters again. Saddest ending to any movie I've ever seen. Went with a whole group of car enthusiasts and not a single dry eye at the end. RIP Paul
the movie was fantastic. The only problem i had was the tribute to paul. It was well done, but they could have done more.
AMAZING MOVIE!!! Great tribute. Well worth seeing.

The original fast and furious film was believable drama and down to earth. It didn't need a sequel but we live in a time when directors would rather turn a movie into a franchise and milk the same idea instead of creating an original idea. Furious 7 as well as the other 5 sequels to the original film in this series have made tons of cash but in the process have sacrificed all realism. Besides a nice ending for the late Paul Walkers character Brian O Connor, Furious 7 is a soulless film that gives us nothing but over the top action scenes and a further soiling of the original films legacy.

Let's begin by turning the clock back briefly: First film good, Second film decent, third film ok, things were going downhill but as far as movie franchises go it could have been worse. Then it got worse. If the rushed storyline and ridiculous underground tunnel chase of the 4th film wasn't when the franchise went into the toilet they gave us The Rock! Yes The Rock: a wwe wrestler and 45 year old man who wears a leotard and pretends to fight other men! He's also an "actor" who's given us such brilliant classics as....oh yeah all those movies he was in suck! Then let's add .... Drumroll!.... Jason Statham! Yes the guy who has stared in more action movies then there are stars in the sky but only made one that was any good (crank). Yes let's take 2 well known celebs and bad actors to add to the cast because of course that helps create realism! Oh and let's bring back Lucas Black because we all know everyone loved his performance in Tokyo Drift so much so that he was fired after only 1film!

Let's be real here everyone it's only this popular because of Paul Walkers death. Like Nirvana before Kurt Cobains suicide this film series was doing well financially but was nowhere near the success it is today breaking box office records. Unlike Nirvana the quality of the product doesn't deserve the ridiculous money it's taking in. People need to boycott movie franchises for this madness to end. If your going to make 7 movies why not just become a tv series? Unfortunately this story will keep continuing as long as you support it but it's 6 and counting sequels are all unjustified.

Franchises should only be allowed when they work. The new direction this franchise started in the 4th film and through Furious 7 is an insult to the fans intelligence. What will they do for fast and furious 8? Maybe they can team up with Dog the bounty hunter and hunt Isis! Oh and for the 9th film they will team up with William Shatner and hunt aliens!

In closing please boycott all sequels to any movie so hollywood will be forced to actually make real movies again.

Rip Paul Walker

-The Reviewer

One last ride.

Furious 7 was the first movie I was really excited to see this year. It really signals the kick-off of "movie season" for me, the summer blockbusters that wait until the heat hits to pop your popcorn and steam the ice from your Coca-Cola. I love the Furious series. Like I said in my review of Fast & Furious 6, it's gone from a movie about an underground street racer to a crew of super heros, doing battle with villains on an unbelievable level. It's like as if a 13 year old boy's imagination has been transplanted to the screen. I hope that in Fast & Furious 8, they battle the Avengers.

Furious 7 continues to build where Fast & Furious 6 left off story-wise. The brother of a fallen villain comes to avenge him (played by Jason Statham). While avoiding him, the Fast crew is also tasked with grabbing an electronic gadget called 'God's Eye' for a U.S. shadow operation, which can track people in real time, wherever they are in the world. How will they grab the gadget from militants while avoiding Statham? With cars, of course. With lots and lots of cars.

You come to a Fast & Furious movie for the stunts. This one doesn't disappoint there. Taking things to yet another level, we have cars dropping out of the sky in the mountains, flying between skyscrapers in Abu Dabi, and screetching through the streets of L.A. There's also a fair bit of hand to hand combat here, and it's well done - Tony Jaa (The Protector, Ong Bak) is introduced to American audiences in Furious 7, and his talent is on full display. It almost made me forget about the pile of crap that was The Protector 2.

The cast is one of the reasons people keep coming back to the Furious series. They've obviously got buckets of chemistry (not including Michelle Rodriguez, who just seems out of place in every scene she shares with anyone) from the years of working together (since 2001). Unfortunately, this marks the last movie of Paul Walker's short career. The movie was not finished when he passed away, but the CGI is so well done that it was never distracting seeing Walker on screen. There were only a few scenes that were obvious to me that there was work done, but it never took me out of the movie. A scene where Brian talks on the phone with Mia was particularly choppy, but I have got to give the editors credit here. What a job they did. The Rock is fabulous as always, Statham was great, and there were a lot of bit cameos from old players in the series.

Furious 7 isn't lacking, however. The dialogue here seems to have gotten worse, something that I didn't think was possible after Fast & Furious 6. The one liners are god awful ("You know the thing about street fights? The street always wins."), with only The Rock getting laughs out of my audience. The story is filled with the same ridiculousness you've come to expect from the series. Statham's character magically appears in any country the crew travels to with the necessary gear to head them off at all times. If you've ever played Friday the 13th on the original NES, he reminds me of Jason. Anywhere, any time. Like he teleports. There are also very little consequences to our characters actions. Destroy three buildings in a foreign country? Next scene - back in L.A. There are maybe 3 cops shown in the entire movie, and their cars are dispatched of instantly. Again, this is par for the course, but it could have been done a bit smarter. There are also a curious amount of ass shots from women in bikinis. Anywhere they go, there's an ass to look at. My pal Moose put it pretty well - there are three speeds to this movie. 1, the rap video - slow motion women dancing or walking from behind set to music. 2, the soap opera with awful dialogue. 3, balls to the wall action.

As everything wraps up, they have a touching tribute for the late Paul Walker with a Vin Diesel voice over. It's a touching moment, and I swear someone was chopping onions in the theater while that was happening.

This wasn't my favorite Fast & Furious installment. Far from it, actually. I think Justin Lin was the perfect director for this, and he moved on to direct the Terminator series. James Wan does pretty well with what he had to work with, but it didn't do for me what 5 & 6 did.

My final score: C+

I've got nothing but praise for this movie.  Here we are, the seventh film in to a long running franchise and it just happens to be one of the best, one of the most unique and one of the most creative yet.  Throughout the Fast and Furious series, the franchise has slowly grown from its humble beginnings as an undercover cop film that featured street racers and fast cars to something bigger and more bombastic with each new entry.  No complaints from this guy either.  I've loved the ride.  Furious 7 to me is the most "blockbuster" film of the series to date.  I honestly don't think this movie was any less exciting or "big" than any Marvel movie I've seen except for maybe Avengers and Winter Soldier.  It was a huge movie, even more ambitious than the 6th which I thought was extremely ambitious in its own right.  This has instantly become one of my favorites in the series easily on Par with #1 and #5 my other two favorites.

  I also wanted to say what I thought about the Paul Walker situation.  The way his character is handled in this film is nothing short of brilliant.  I know the film was only half finished when he passed away, but you would never know it.  The character "Brian" has no less screen time than he has always had.  And keeping this spoiler free, the way they handled writing him out of further movies was straight up brilliant, touching and moved at least this guy to tears.  Honestly.  It was a tragedy that Paul Walker died so young and his unfortunate passing must have created a huge problem for the production of this film that could've ended up leaving it a complete disaster.  Luckily that was not the case.  I would love to shake the hands of everyone involved in making this movie for the way that they handled Paul's passing and finishing the filming with his character still completely intact.  It was an outstanding tribute to an integral player in this franchise and an actor taken before his time.  I'm sure it was not an easy undertaking.  The creative team behind this film all deserve all the kudos in the world for the most respectful send off of Paul Walker they could have possibly come up with.  I'm sure his family and friends would be proud, as would he.

FURIOUS 7 delivers more over the top action, extremely attractive tough women, and of course badass cars. Originally titled FAST AND FURIOUS 7 the film was slated for a July 2014 release, but around Thanksgiving 2013 the world received tragic news that Paul Walker died in a car accident while hosting a charity event. Universal Studios and the film makers shut down production temporarily to mourn the loss of a great man. Paul Walker's 2 brothers stepped in to help finish the movie.

FURIOUS 7 takes directly after FAST AND FURIOUS 6, and the sins of London have follow Dominic Toretto and his family to his LA home, as Deckhart Shaw (Jason Statham) seeks revenge for Toretto's family for crippling his brother Owen Shaw. But lets be honest, you don't see a Fast and Furious movie for story (like TRANSFORMERS) you see it for pure, over the top fun and FURIOUS 7 delivers that with ease.

Newcomers include Jason Statham, Kurt Russell, Ronda Rousey, Djimon Hounson, Tony Jaa, and a actress from Game of Thrones who plays a mysterious character. And just like Dwayne Johnson from FAST FIVE, they all fit perfectly in this movie. Most notably Kurt Russell and Jason Statham. Kurt Russell fits perfectly in this movie and plays a likable fun character. And Jason Statham for the first time plays the a villain in a movie, and he's also perfect in the movie.

Vin Diesel, Paul Walker, Ludacris, Tyrese Gibson, Jordana Brewster, Dwayne Johnson, and Michelle Rodriguez return and are good as ever. But you might be disappointed if you love The Rock's character Hobbs, cause he's not in the movie that much, even though there's a reason why.

FURIOUS 7 is the best FAST AND FURIOUS to date, and the end of the movie a amazing, emotional, farewell tribute to Paul Walker. Trust me when you see the movie, you will shed a tear at the end.

As fate would have it bad guy Owen Shaw (Luke Evans) has a vengeful brother Deckard (Jason Statham) who seeks out our heroes. Letty (Michelle Rodriguez) still has memory issues. Deckard shows up in LA (and anywhere else in the world at random) as "the sins of London have followed us home."

The film gets a bit weird in it effort to create over-the-top action. It seems Deckard is former British special ops who is an expert at being a ghost. His own unit is attempting to take him out as well. This becomes "a war between shadows and ghosts" as head spook Kurt Russell claims. Now in order to find Deckard, who always finds them, they must first rescue Ramsey (Nathalie Emmanuel) who has the ultimate hacking chip called God's Eye whereby they can locate anybody in the world. This way they can track Deckard who is hunting them. The crew goes on a world tour.

The film includes cars parachuting from planes; a cat fight in formal wear (Ronda Rousey): building jumping; bullet proof everything; cars with no airbags; and the destruction of LA. The action was so incredibly impossible it made me laugh along with the cheesy lines. Oh yes. They re-invented the word "cliff hanger."

There was a nice tribute to Paul Walker at the end of the film.

Nine Things About the Film "Furious 7"

1. It's kinda cool to see the fast and furious gang back again. But the series now needs to fit in the category of "fantasy", because everybody has become magical, indestructible superheroes, and the plot has absolutely nothing to do with reality. And I understand why the title was shortened to "Furious 7". The movie is kind of slow until the last 45 minutes.

2. For some reason, James Wan directed this movie. Up to now, he has only directed horror movies (he's most famous for "Saw").

3. There are actually two plots in the film. The first is a continuation of part 6. Jason Statham plays Deckard, the brother of the bad guy in the last film. Statham is probably best known as the guy in "The Transporter", and he plays basically the same character in this film. I suspect that Deckard really is the Transporter, and this is what he does between jobs.

4. The second plot is about a secret organization in the government that is looking for a hacker. Even though they have all the resources, computer experts, and hundreds of agents, they can't get the hacker. So they hire these six renegade car racers to do it.

5. The technology in the film is very interesting. It turns out that if you put a bomb on the front porch of a house, the house will explode from the inside. Also, there is now a little computer chip that allows you to look at every camera, computer, and cell phone in the world, at the same time.  Oh yeah, and if you want to override the security system of one of the richest men in the world, all you have to do is open the phone outlet and cut the orange wire.

6.  Paul Walker died halfway through filming, so the script had to be rewritten, and Walker's brothers were used as stand-ins for him. Computer effects were added onto the brothers to make them look like Paul. Yes, Paul Walker has become computer-generated.

7.  Lucas Black, the star of the 3rd "Fast and Furious" film, has a cameo in this movie. He has signed on to be in part 8 and 9.

8. The film came up with a classy way to write Paul Walker out of the story, while guaranteeing that the series will continue. And the best part of the movie is the very end, which is a tribute to Paul.

9. This movie is dumb, loud, and ridiculous. But if you know what you're getting into (and you should, considering this is the 7th movie), it's not terrible.

Director James Wan who is known mainly for horror movies (Insidious, Saw, The Conjuring), was new to the Fast and Furious franchise. He had the task of making a 7th film that is and remains popular to movie-goers and fans alike.  I have been anticipating this movie for a LONG time, and today I will review the movie Furious 7.

Set after the rollercoaster that was Fast and Furious 6, we see Dom take Letty to a familiar event known as race wars-in hopes to trigger her memory. Meanwhile, Brian is also behind the wheel; the wheel of a minivan taking his son Jack to school. Over in London however, we meet a man Deckard Shaw who is at a hospital visiting his injured brother Owen Shaw (Fast and Furious 6's main villain) and seeing his brother in this condition, he swears revenge on those who put his brother in his hospital bed. And so begins Furious 7.

Returning as Dominic Toretto, Vin Diesel gives another good performance in the movie. You mess with a member of Dominic's family, then he definitely shows why that is a BAD idea. Dwayne Johnson stars as Luke Hobbs and does a fantastic job. Though Hobb's is not in the movie a lot, he delivers his usual one-liners and delivers some memorable action scenes; especially the one between Hobbs and Deckard Shaw. And for those of you that read my Fast Five review, I said that there was going to be a "familiar action star- a damn good one at that". And that action star is  Jason Statham as primary antagonist Deckard Shaw. In my opinion, he did a really good job. Not only does Shaw has the moves, he has a ton of artillery, and some unexpected allies that assist in his chaos. I had a blast watching Statham as Shaw. Michelle Rodriguez portrays Letty Ortiz and I feel she does A LOT better in Furious 7 than she has in the previous films. Tyrese Gibson and Ludacris provide the movie with humor as Roman and Tej, while martial artists Ronda Rousey and Tony Jaa kick a lot of serious butt as Kara and Kiet. Nathalie Emmanuel and actor Djimon Hounsou star as Megan Ramsey and Mose Jakande and both of them do a really great job in the movie. Kurt Russell stars as Mr. Nobody(that is his name) and does an exceptional job assisting Dominic and the crew in tracking Shaw. And finally, actor Paul Walker makes his final appearance as the man fans have come to know as Brian O'Conner. Not only does he have some incredible action scenes(which I will speak on in a minute), but the Furious 7 does a great job in providing fans with a touching tribute to Paul Walker. Great job by the cast.

Story wise, Its may seem like Furious 7's main point is revenge. But I like how the movie kept the theme of family from Fast and Furious 6  and shows the importance and bond of a family. On to the action scenes, I can not say enough about how well the action scenes are in the movie. The fight scenes are choreographed and sequenced so smoothly. I especially enjoyed (MILD SPOILER) Hobbs vs Shaw, and all of Brian's fight scenes were nicely detailed. What is even more likable is that Furious 7 knows exactly what type of movie it is and delivers in terms of action, the actors/actresses(especially Rodriguez, Johnson, Walker, and Statham), the gorgeous scenery and set locations of the movie, the direction of James Wan, and because Furious 7 keeps the viewer's attention the entire duration of the movie. While I would certainly like to see the franchise end here out of respect to Paul Walker, I have heard rumors that there will be not only 8th, but a 9th, and 10th movie. But if you needed any further detail of why you should see this movie then I will end my review just by saying GO SEE Furious 7 because it is

A Great Experience

I saw this movie opening night and it literally was the best movie I've ever seen in my life, and now i can't stop thinking about it and all the touching and action packed moments. The part i liked the most was toward the end of the movie how it made look back at my life and made me appreciate what i have. Absolutely in love with this movie and i cannot wait till it comes out on DVD to add to my fast and furious collection

Just saw Furious 7 and will probably go back to see it again for the moments I missed the first time.  I have seen all of the movies in this franchise and look forward to each new installment.  The actors have grown in abilities, and in the sense of family .  Granted the action has increased from being somewhat plausible to crashing a sports car through high rise buildings in a foreign country.  But people, we go to the movies for entertainment, not reality!  After all, we have accepted, loved,  and spent lots of money on other movies that were beyond belief.  When is the last time your sister decided to marry a talking teddy bear?  Do you think all the displays in your local museum come to life after dark?  Don't forget "Beam me up, Scotty" or your sports car changing into a robot.  Suspension of belief is what we need sometimes.

We can get enough reality on the nightly news where the bad guys seem to be winning.  I love to see movies where it finally looks like the good guys can fight fire with fire.  Dom isn't afraid to throw down and neither are any of his 'family'. They get several extra points for showing the strength and abilities in women, especially Letty, instead of just throwing in mindless eye candy. All movies have some beautiful women just for the sake of showing some skin...but at least they let Letty be strong, physical, as well as showing her emotions and beauty without having to take her clothes off every other scene. Great character, glad they brought her back.  Dom's character needed Letty.  It is refreshing to see an alpha that fights FOR his family instead going home after his day at work and abusing his wife and kids.  And he isn't ashamed to say that  family is what is important.
After watching the franchise all these years, it feels as if  they are family to us.  It is sad that one of the family is gone...we will miss Paul and the films he would have made.  They did well at honoring him in the completion of this movie and a beautiful job of saying "farewell" to Brian.  Families have loss and go on with life.  I would be terrible for this franchise family to call it quits and unravel  because one of them is no longer here.

of this.  There are many more entertaining chapters and storylines that could be explored.

The Fast & Furious series occupies a very unique place for movie lovers. One the one hand, its without a shadow of a doubt the most successful original franchise Hollywood has seen in decades, and has built a loyal following of fans who will accept any amount of over-the-top hokum it throws at them. On the other side are those who don't understand why people care about these obviously terrible movies. What the latter group fails to get, and the bombastic, gratuitous, and pure awesomeness of Furious 7 won't convince them, is how deeply personal these movies are when boiled down to their very essence.

No greater example of the close-knit ties between this franchise and its fans exists than in Furious 7, which sadly marks the final screen role for the late Paul Walker. His death in the middle of production creates a chasm that simply can't be filled, even with his twin brothers filling in noticeably in various scenes. But it's more than just the physical stuff we miss. The oft-cited theme of "family' is pumped up more than ever in Chris Morgan's screenplay, and every scene with Walker brings a little pang of hurt. While there's a deeply sentimental tone throughout, Furious 7 is also the biggest, loudest, and "holy crap that was incredible!!!" chapter yet. It's like injecting Red Bull straight into your veins and pouring liquid speed into your eyeballs.

Once considered the red-headed stepchild, 2006's 'Tokyo Drift' is now one of the most important installments as things finally came full circle after the death of Han (Sung Kang) at the hands of Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham), the older brother to Owen Shaw who was seemingly killed in Fast & Furious 6. Deckard is an unstoppable force, and after making his presence felt in explosive fashion, he goes toe-to-toe in the ultimate machismo showdown against Agent Hobbs (Dwayne Johnson), leaving Hobbs laid up in the hospital. If that doesn't establish Shaw as the baddest man on the planet nothing else will.

While Shaw seeks revenge against Dom and the rest of his family, Brian (Walker) is entering a new phase of his life as a father and husband, so surviving the war to come is more paramount than ever. Letty (Michelle Rodriguez) is still struggling to cope with her near death and subsequent amnesia, with Dom basically doing a four-wheeled version of The Vow to jog her memory. The action once again takes them around the world, with help from a covert agent played by Kurt Russell, plus a stop in Tokyo to revisit Lucas Black's 'Tokyo Drift' character. That scene doesn't work out as well as it should since the flashbacks don't jibe with the present, but it's still a cool bit of nostalgia and world-building. They also pick up a new recruit in Ramsey (played by the incredibly hot Nathalie Emmanuel), a computer hacker with a super MacGuffin device capable of spying on anyone. And of course Roman (Tyrese Gibson) and Tej (Ludacris) trade quips in the middle of pulling death-defying feats Superman wouldn't dare.

And let's talk about those feats because Furious 7 is basically one mind-blowing set piece after another, designed to evoke the loudest possible response from its fans. In terms of plot this may be the weakest yet but incoming director James Wan doesn't give a crap about all of that. He's dropping cars from airplanes and flying cars between buildings! In one incredibly well-choreographed set piece Wan hits us with literally everything he can think of: car chases, armed buses, cliff diving, gun fights, a brawl between Walker and martial arts superstar Tony Jaa, sniper rifles, Djimon Hounsou in slick shades...damned if it doesn't have everything a genre fan could want. The only thing missing is a cat fight and that comes later when Rodriguez throws down with UFC champ Ronda Rousey. What's most impressive is that this is really Wan's first time tackling this kind of genre, having built his career on horrors. Youd never know it, though, and clearly he's been taking some tips from The Raid in the use of wild, kinetic camera angles. The hand-to-hand combat is faster, the vehicular mayhem more insane than ever. Even if this turns out to be Wan's only film before moving on he has made quite the impression. Making less of an impact are Rousey and Jaa, whose talents aren't given nearly enough time to shine. On the other hand, Johnson is bolder and more oiled up than ever as Hobbs. In a film full of superheroes he's the most superhero-y of them all, not even broken bones can stop him!

For those who wonder why these movies are so successful? It's really quite simple. As over-the-top and stupidly unbelievable as many of the action scenes are, they are balanced nicely an emotional sincerity that is easy to understand. None of these characters are especially deep, we all get that, but we recognize that they would all die to protect one another. That's an incredibly powerful thing that the franchise has tapped into, and Furious 7 keeps that tradition alive even when turning the page.
I love it ''
This movie is insane.

In my opinion, it's officially over. This multi-billion dollar muscle-car franchise has ended. If Vin Diesel tries again, it will be a big mistake. There is nowhere to go after this one, particularly when we all know Paul Walker is dead and we see his character, through the wizardry of body doubles, CGI and scenes already in the can before his death, take another path. The last few indelible minutes of this film are deeply affecting, the audience was riveted.

Director James Wan ("Saw") specializes in action movies and this one is waaay over the top. One of the things have I appreciated about this series has been the skillful stunt driving and the minimal computer generated imaging. This is NOT one of them; HOWEVER, the emphasis on family values, bravery, loyalty and trust which has been the heart of the franchise, is unchanged, so in my opinion they can leave with their heads' unbowed.

We see (I'm abbreviating the name for the returnees):
  * Vin Diesel ("Furious") Dominic is trying to help his wife Letty remember events in their lives before her traumatic brain injury.
  * Michelle Rodriguez ("Furious") Letty feels she died on the date she sees on her tombstone; she doesn't even remember they are married.
  * Paul Walker ("Furious") Brian worries that he's not tough enough to face domesticity...and he already misses the bullets. But it's hard to see his modest little bungalow blown to smithereens.
  * Jordana Brewster ("Furious") Mia wants her husband to accept his family and be happy to give up the excitement of his past life.
  * Tyrese Gibson ("Furious") Roman is hilarious as the alpha-alpha of the group (you've gotta see it!). He makes the plans....
  * Ludacris ("Furious") Our favorite hacker Tej, may have found a soul mate in the tech wizard they are trying to rescue.
  * Dwayne Johnson ("Furious") Watch Hobbs rid himself of a nuisance, the arm cast from an early scuffle, by flexing those ridiculous biceps.
  * Lucas Black ("Furious") No real need to include Sean, but that Southern accent is so charming.... And he DOES explain stuff.
  * Jason Statham ("Furious") Deckard Shaw is the Energizer Bunny who JUST WON"T STOP! His brother was caught by our heroes in the last movie, so Deckard is out for revenge.
  * Nathalie Emmanuel ("Game of Thrones") Ramsey is the ultimate hacker; she has devised a brilliant new program that will revolutionize law enforcement. I like the way she immediately categorizes everyone!
  * Kurt Russell ("The Art of the Steal") Mr. Nobody must have the deus ex machina, the plot device that is the central issue: a brilliant digital tracking system that makes everything up until now, absolutely archaic.

Over the years, because of the lack of profanity, the skill of the stunt drivers and the emphasis on family values (including prayer before a meal), I have been intrigued by this series. I have taken great pride in its huge success, both domestic and international, and hope the franchise ends on this high note. I will own the DVD just for the last few minutes. I've preordered it from Amazon.

Ok, before I start talking about the film, let me just say that they really show WAY too much of this film in the trailers, TV spots, behind the scenes features, etc. One TV commercial showed WAY too much of the ending, so, not cool.
In this film, Deckard Shaw(Jason Statham) is hunting the team to avenge his brother Owen from the last film. Dom(Vin Diesel), Brian(Paul Walker) and the rest of the team set out to avenge Han and to find Shaw before he finds them.
In a nutshell, this is another great Fast and Furious movie, bringing the immense fun, amazing action, compelling morals, laugh out loud humor and unforgettable characters back and better than ever!
The plane drop scene was awesome!
The entire Abu Dahbi part of the movie was a lot of fun!
I loved Ramsey! She was great! She's a very welcome new addition to the team!
Kurt Russel was the real scene-stealer as Mr. Nobody, a mysterious yet very cheerful and charismatic government agent.
Michelle Rodriguez really stepped it up as Letty. Not that there was anything wrong with how she played her before. She gets emotional on a few occasions and she does it very well.
There are some shocking revelations about characters that we've known for a while, the last of which is really nice.
The cast of Tokyo Drift finally returns after 9 years... but then leaves 60 seconds later...... oh well.
And, the scene everyone is talking about, the ending really is a beautiful and extremely emotional farewell to both an unforgettable character and, from what I hear, an amazing human being.
In closing, Furious 7 is another outstanding installment in what really is the greatest film saga of our generation.

you ain't gonna be sorry at all. Very action-packed, humorous, emotional and genuinely
touching.
