This movie get 3 stars because the movie went away from what truly made "The Fast And Furious" is the racing and the exotic cars.

Theatrical review.  Possible spoilers.  In what I expect will be one of the biggest movies of the year, the series may also have produced the best chapter yet.  This edition picks up close to where the last one ended.  After dispatching bad guy, Owen Shaw (Luke Evans) in the earlier film we see his bad-ass older brother, Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham) pledge revenge on Dom Toretto (Vin Diesel) and his crew beginning with his government accomplice Hobbs (Dwayne Johnson).

We know that Shaw isn't to be trifled with early on as he and Hobbs go mano y mano with only Hobbs being sent to the hospital.  Shaw, having hacked Hobbs's computer has the names and locations of everyone and begins his vengeful killing spree in Tokyo and almost gets Dom, his sister Mia (Jordana Brewster), his new brother-in-law, Brian (Paul Walker) and their toddler, with a bomb.  After this happens, Dom gets that look in his eye and vows to go after Shaw.

In a secondary plotline, a secretive quasi-government unit headed by "Mr. Nobody" (a scene stealing Kurt Russell), wants Dom and his crew to rescue a tech-genius named Ramsey (Nathalie Emmanuel from "Game of Thrones").  She's developed a system that can track anyone in the world by hacking into traffic cameras, computers, cell phones and any and all electronic devices and using sophisticated facial recognition software.  If the crew can pull it off, Dom is promised access in order to track down Shaw.

This is all just an excuse to kick-start a couple of hours of non-stop action sequences, the best of which is Dom, Brian, Letty (Michelle Rodrigues) who still has memory loss, Roman (Tyrese Gibson) and Tej (Ludacris) sky-dive...along with their cars...onto an otherwise obscure mountain highway in Azerbaijan.  This undetected approach allows them to find and rescue Ramsey, but only after a series of remarkably staged and executed stunts involving cars, stunt drivers and the actors.

Unlike previous F & F films, I found these to be tension-filled in addition to the action.  Djimon Hounsou shows up here as the leader of the group who kidnapped Ramsey, along with Asian action star Tony Jaa who has a fearsome fight with Brian in this sequence and later in the film.  All of this nonsense clears the way for some even more ridiculous, but downright brilliant scenes shot in Abu Dhabi where Dom launches a $3.5 million super car through a series of glassy skyscrapers.

Eventually the gang returns to L. A. with Shaw and Jakande (Hounsou) hot on their trail with the "God's Eye" device in their pocket.  In addition to some terrific action sequences and well-choreographed fights, the movie concludes with an emotional send off to Walker who died in the middle of shooting the film in 2013.  While it plays within the confines of the script, it is also an obvious fond farewell from the hearts of the actors.  Yeah, it's authentic and it's touching.

Ever since the first fast and the furious came out in 2001 I was hooked. It's crazy how long this franchise has been, and the characters and how they are a family in real life. When you have someone in your life for that long it's incredible to see their relationships grow. Furious 7 was very amazing! It was a bit long but it was expected, there were tons and tons of fighting scenes, I think they could've reduced that by 10 minutes. Before going in to see the movie I heard Paul completed 85% of his scenes, and the rest were going to be played by his brothers. I couldn't tell until the last 15-20 min of the film thy had his brothers do the scenes but they digitally altered the face to make it look identical to Paul's. No matter what, they did a great job on the entire film, the ending was just such so emotional though. I cried at a few parts in the film because you see the characters true emotion not just acting. At the end is where you see it the most, the second to last scene where they are all at the beach you can see it in their faces and thinking "Paul this is for you brother" I balled my eyes out. In all honesty I do not think they should go on and do an 8th or 9th movie. I heard it was based in new York and that's why Kirt russel was in this movie, because he will be in the next. They should leave it how it ended. Without Paul there should be no more it's just not the same. "If one day speed kills me, do not cry because I was smiling" -Paul Walker (Beautiful Angel)

Furious 7

 By the time a movie franchise has reached number seven we can expect one of two outcomes.  We could well expect that the film turns out to be loud, expensive and flat, with all imagination long used up.  Or we can find a film that has a kind of perfection of its type.  In Furious 7 we have the later.  We have a film that precisely meets our expectations.  It may be loud, expensive and predicable-even silly if we were silly enough to examine too closely some of the plot set ups-but we just don't care.  Even big summer action movies have a range from dross to gold and this one shine bight yellow.
 We give a hoot because after so many of the Furious films we recognize the characters.  And the direction keeps things moving in interesting way.  First the characters.
 Dominic Toretto (Vin Diesel) has an interesting and very close family.  They race cars and fight bad guys for the government.  Well, sometimes they have to fight the government but usually everyone makes up afterward.  Don and his people also wreck cars and kill people, often in spectacular ways.  But we end up caring about Dom's family nearly as much as he does.  Brian (the late Paul Walker), once an enemy of Dom's now has married Don's sister Mia (Mordana Brewster).  Brian, Mia and their child are safely in the family.  But love runs deep in the family and not always along blood lines.  Comrades in arms are also granted family status by the ruler, Dom.  These include Letty (Michelle Rodriguez) Dom's amnesiac wife-she doesn't remember that she and Dom are married.  Characters Roman and Tej are played by music crossover stars Tyrese Gibson and Ludacris.  New comer to the family is Nathalie Emmanuel (Game of Thrones) who plays Ramsey, a computer hacker and plot hub.
Dwayne The Rock Johnson plays federal cop Hobbs who might also have family standing.
 The villain is played by tough guy Jason Statham.  In one of the best bits in the film Statham goes nose to nose with The Rock in a very well staged battle.  We want to see if a big, fast fighter,
Statham, can beat an even bigger, stronger but maybe not quite so fast fighter, Johnson.  For a back up villain the producers give us Djimon Hounsou as the brains behind the forces of evil.  Also featured are Kurt Russell, Noel Gugliemi and Lucas Black.  We were pleased to see our favorite tough girl Ronda Rousey make an appearance as a bodyguard.  Rousey won an Olympic medal in Judo for the USA before going on the full fight mode as a UFO champion.  She and Michelle Rodriguez have a splendid knock down drag out fight in the middle of a fancy party.
 Which brings us to the direction of James Wan.  We know Wan best from his directorial efforts in Saw and The Conjuring.  He believably drops high performance automobiles out of a C-17 cargo plane and we buy right into it.  It turns out that the technology of GPS directed parachutes actually exists, which makes it even cooler.  He also jumps a sports car from one skyscraper to another.  Twice.  Wow.
 Writer Gary Scott has penned four other of the Furious films.  He understands that his job is to get his characters into dangerous situations so that they can get to safety in loud, dangerous and exciting ways.  Which is exactly what he does.  And director James Wan makes the gang look really cool while they do it.  Which explains why we go see these things in our millions.
 These guys spent a reported $250 million to make this slam bang speed and explosion extravaganza, which makes it almost imperative to go watch it.  I mean, they went to all that trouble to make the film, we should go and see it, right?  Definitely right.
 The PG-13 rated film lasts a good long two hours and 17 minutes.
 Actor Paul Walker lost his life in an unrelated car wreck during shooting.  Director Wan carefully shot around the loss of the actor using Walker's two brothers as body doubles, among other techniques.  This results in a film that the uninformed viewer would not suspect had this problem.
 The film ends with a lovely and touching homage to Paul Walker.
 Four saw blades to this opening film of the 2015 summer blockbuster season.

Six months after their duel in London they are free but Brian misses being a policeman. Shaw's older brother is a Black Ops (The Expendables) guy and wants to go after Dom's crew. He visits Hobbs for information and WWE follows. Then he blows up Dom's house. A guy by the name of Mr. Nobody shares with Dom that a computer programmer has created the tracking platform from Person of Interest: Season 1 and that Dom can use it to find Shaw as he is a shadow. Dom and the crew rescue the programmer who explains that the program is with a friend. They go to get the program. They end up back at home where it becomes Blue Thunder (1983) [HD]/Drones. At times cartoonish.

I am a big fan of James Wan. I think he has made some of the most thrilling horrors in recent years. His films often leave me wanting more and I am never shy of revisiting them after the passage of some time. When I heard he is directing Fast and Furious (a franchise I'd never been interested in) I wondered what he will bring to the table in an action based plot.

The last film of the franchise I saw was Fast and Furious 2. This was back in the day. Don't know why I thought they may have improved. Oh yes, its the people who've been watching these films. They said I must watch the 5th one and all but I never bothered until right now.

Where do I begin? The story line is terrible, the plot and execution is extremely cliche. There are 1 second action scenes where you are made to just simply stop blinking. The action is over the top, completely made up and absolutely trashy.

Did anyone watch "White House Down" ? This is that bad.
Did you watch Pacific Rim? It is that bad.

I don't think I am watching a Blockbuster anytime soon because it saddens me to see the level Hollywood stoops to. I don't mean all Blockbusters but some films are so poorly executed with no storyline.

There is a scene involving a car crash through three buildings in Dubai. The crew would never pull it off in real life without being arrested on 67 counts and being lashed to death. I think it was a pretty good scene.

By the way, I don't believe in 3D so went for the 2D version. My wife noticed I was getting very fidgety halfway during the film. I felt such a huge sigh of relief after we walked out shortly before the end. We were the only ones I guess. The crowd seemed enthralled.

I think if you enjoyed any of the older films, there's a good chance you will enjoy this one.

It was cringe worthy to watch Vin Diesel, Paul Walker and even The Rock. They were all very bad in this film but blame the storyline or whatever or maybe even all three.

SPOILER FREE!

I just want to preface this review by stating I have been a fan of this series since it first came out and have kind of grown up as I watched it.  I was 19 and in college with no responsibilities, single, and a care free life the first time I saw Fast and Furious.  I am now 33 married and just had our second child.  Given the themes of this movie, the evolution of the characters, only make this movie even more poignant.

The core of this series has always been about family, and the 7th film is no different.  It truly takes the dramatic core of family and takes it to another level.  As a person who has grown along with the series and watched the characters grow and have families in the movies, this movie truly emphasizes something in life that few action movies are able to stress, and that is Family.  Dom states "I don't have friends.  I have family." And that is exactly what this movie is about.  The performances feel so real, especially given the knowledge that Paul Walker passed during filming adds even more emotional weight to many of the scenes.  I almost feel as though it is almost Vin Diesel himself talking to his compadres at times rather then the character talking to other characters.  That is how real it seemed at times.

Plot Synopsis:  As seen from the previews, this movie is about revenge.  However, there is an added twist to this.  I will not state exactly, but I will say that I felt that Jason Statham was quite underused in this movie.  I felt that his character had minimal development and was a stereotypical "bad guy on a revenge trip."  As in any Fast movie the action set pieces are too notch and require a hefty dose of suspension of disbelief,  but isn't that way you came to see these films anyway.  I did feel the last 35 minute action sequence could have been shortened by 5-10 min. Or so.  But the other scenes were the perfect length and never felt bloated.

In regards to how they finished the movie despite not having Paul walker. Only in a couple of instances was the CGI noticeable, but if you were not looking specifically for it, I feel that most people would not notice.  It was very well done, and I truly felt he was pretty much in the whole move.

However,  after 2 hours of nonstop action and thrills you are treated to one of the greatest endings in cinematic history.  The last ten minutes are worth the price of admission alone.  Congrats to Universal, the writing staff, director and the actors for putting together the best possible ending I could imagine.  I, as well as everyone else, was wondering how they could walk the fine line of paying tribute without being tacky or being overly emotional such that you felt like it was a funeral. Well they did it.  It was PERFECT,  and if you can't relate to the ending in some fashion then you are likely a robot.  The performances at the end felt more genuine than almost anything I have ever seen on film.  They will be talking about this ending for eternity.

Watch this movie.  You won't regret it.  Just bring some tissues.

Just watched this movie and it's over-the-top. There's a good reason why all the critics are calling this movie ridiculous, but still giving it incredibly high ratings. This movie doesn't take itself too seriously and understands the fans are watching it for the action scenes and great one liners. No posthumous Oscar will be awarded to Paul Walker, but, it does provide a nice send off just the same. It was touching watching the scenes where you could tell it was he's brothers filling in for him, particularly the final shots of the movie.

FURIOUS 7 - my review: What started as an experiment back in 2001,  this series has transformed itself into a bonafide blockbuster franchise. Exciting action sequences, vehicular carnage and relentless hand-to-hand combats - F7 delivers a powerhouse! I have to say, what really separates this film from its predecessors is its emotional depth between the characters; throughout, this film gives you thrilling action, It'll make you laugh, and the grand finale showdown will even get you teary eyed. The film isn't only about slick cars and explosions, it's also about friends, family, trust and love.  Hats off to Director James Wan and Universal -  despite his tragic death midway through production completing 80% of his scenes, Walker remains a key figure in the film, with his 2 younger brothers' clever use of their body doubles and CGI effects. An emotional, but bittersweet farewell to Paul Walker. #Furious7 #RaceInParadise #DriftInTheClouds

FURIOUS 7 is outstanding. It is emotionally charged from start to finish. It went far beyond my expectations. Paul Walker was an amazing actor and had a certain screen presence we will miss. This is an out-and-out amazing film in some respects. The entire cast was perfect. FURIOUS 7 blew me away at times and disappointed at others. Somehow the entire cast and crew went far beyond anyone could imagine in what seems like a tribute to Paul Walker. I loved parts of it and felt let down in some of the scenes that looked a bit contrived. The film making in FURIOUS 7 is some of the best I have ever seen for this series, but once again it some very weak moments.

They pushed the envelope and went far beyond and perhaps too far at times. The action, the story, the characters and a lot of emotion make this one of the best films of this series, yet something seemed lacking.  Paul will be missed. In the final analysis he seemed like an appendage to this film, simply just a footnote and that was sad. Brian Tyler composed a score that is full of drive, energy and emotion. It is one of his best. The finale is a must see. It is just unbelievable and perhaps that is the underlying problem with FURIOUS 7.
